Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:To locate a choker not located in a jewelry box or boutique where would you go? Choices:  A: jewelry store B: neck C: jewlery box D: jewelry box E: boutique<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationales:<n>1) I would go to a jewelry store because this is the only place where I can find jewelry.<n><n>#### 20<n><n>Input: In order to get to the 9th floor, one must take at least $900 to the elevator. How much money do you have?<n>Rationales:- I will take exactly 900, because the first 500 is $0 so the next 400 is $900.<n>Elevator cost $900<n>I have $900 <n>I am ok!<n>#### 0<n>Answer: 0<n><n>### Instructions :- <n>There are no instructions given<n><n>### Input<n>There is no data given<n><n>### Rationale<n>There is no data in the input so i do nothing.<n><n>### Answer<n>None.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The only baggage the woman checked was a drawstring bag, where was she heading with it? Choices:  A: garbage can B: military C: jewelry store D: safe E: airport<n><n>### Response:		<n>If only the woman checked her baggage in a drawstring bag then it should be her trash that has her things in it.<n><n>If her baggage is a drawstring bag then she also travelled with a drawstring bag to the garbage can.<n>She headed to the jewelry store with her jewelry and she can also put that in the garbage can if she wants.<n>#### Other choices:<n>We can look at one by one where the bag could have been heading.<n>\`\`\`<n>1. A: garbage can<n><n>\`\` If she checked only her baggage then all her things will have to go in it.<n>\`\```<n>2. B: military<n><n>\`\if the only thing that she was travelling was her baggage then she surely would check it in the military and put everything in the garabge can after that.<n>\`\`'<n>3. C: jewelery store<n><n>\`\If she only took her jewelery to the garbage then it surely must have been checked in in a drawstring bag.<n>So A seems the most logical answer.<n>#### 1<n>Answer: A (garbage can)<n><n>### Input : Three pairs of pants were worn by John. He had been through 16 washers. Each cycle costed $0.29. How much did he pay in total for all of the washers?<n>Answers:16 x 0.29 = <<16 X 0.29=4.5>>4.5<n>Total payments = 4.5 + 3 x 4.5 = <<4.5+3X4.5=28>>28.00<n>#### 28<n>Answer: $28.00 (USD)<n><n>### Instructions:<n>#### Note: This question had been inactive for few years.. but I remember being able to answer these questions. However, I have not taken any math courses after 8th grade and am a 15 year old..<n>#### What are the odds of getting a two out of six when picking a single die?<n>#### Choices: A: 1 out of 10 B: 1 out of six C: 1 out of three D: impossible<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where do you put your grapes just before checking out? Choices:  A: mouth B: grocery cart C: super market D: fruit basket E: fruit market<n><n>### Response:		Fruit market<n><n>### Input<n>```Bank Teller: I am ready for you. What do you want to do with your money? There is a 10% service fee if you pay in quarters or 6% if you pay in nickels. There is no fee if you pay with a check.<n>Teller: Do you want to do your business with a check or with cash? Cash costs $0.25 or $0.04 per $1. You want to get cash change of $.30 at any time.<n>Teller: Is there a fee?”<n>### Response<n>```Bank T<n>I got to get the right change back so i got to choose a:<n>```Teller<n>I got to choose one b: c: D: b: d: b: d: I will just get cash. I do not care about quarters.<n>```Teller<n>What?!?! I want change.<n>```Teller:<n>I don’t care about the change.<n>Because I don’t care about change!<n>```Teller<n>You do not care about cents, then why pay 10% extra.<n>```Teller T<n>I do not have 1/8 cents<n>### Input<n>##### Choice A<n>Gloria is buying 1.2 gallons of gas. At the gas pump, there are 36 gallons of gas. If the pump takes 23 seconds to fill up 1 gallon, how long will it take to fill up half a tank?<n>##### Choice B<n>Dennis has $1.20. In the vending machine, he can get 5 cookies for 25 cents and 5 soda cups for 25 cnts. If he chooses to get 16 snacks and drinks, how much will he have left?<n>##### Choices C and D:<n>Sara pays $4.25 for 12 pizzas. If each pie cost $3.50 and they take 30 seconds to make, how long does it take to make 12 pizzs?<n>##### Answer<n>A: 6 seconds to fill half a tank of gas.<n>B: 6 seconds to complete 16 of items for 10 cents per item.

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The shopkeeper tells me that the cheaper the book, the higher the percentage increase for tax.<n>How many percent extra would I have to pay for this book?<n><n>### Response<n><n>**The cheaper price, the higher the percentage. A cheaper price means the price is low, and a low number will be close to 0%.**<n><n>#### 15%<n>Answer: 15%<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The president is the leader of what institution? Choices:  A: walmart B: white house C: country D: corporation E: government<n><n>### Response:		If the word was walmart, I would say it's a c store<n>If the word was white house, I would say it is a government<n>If the word was country, I would say it was a country<n>If the word was corporation, I would say it was the same as white<n>If the word was government, I would say it  was a country<n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What kind of driving leads to accidents? Choices:  A: stressful B: dangerous C: fun D: illegal E: deadly<n><n>### Response:		I think that dangerous driving leads to accidents.<n><n>### Input<n>What was the total amount of money invested by the three men to buy the hotdog stand? Choices: 	A: $80 B: $100 C: $130 D: $200 E: $300<n><n>### Response<n>The men invested $80 and $50 and $10. So $80 + $50 + $10 = <<80+50+10=140>>140<n>### Input: How old was the woman in 2000? Choices: A: 24 B: 26 C: 28 D: 30 E: 32<n><n>###Rationales<n>The woman was in 2001: 1999 - 2 years + 1 for turning 2 + 1 for turning B for becoming 26<n>###Input:What type of relationship? Choices: A. Sister B. Mother C. Grandmother D. Teacher E. Wife<n><n>###Response:<n>It seems that the two women are sisters because "My sister looks just like her."<n><n>### Response to Problems<n><n>> **Note:** Problems may seem challenging as to the nature of the problems are to test you not the programming. <n><n>The `if` and `else` statements are important as it checks for a condition and if certain conditions are satisfied then it performs certain action else it doesn't perform the actions.<n><n>To solve problems you should also consider using nested `if` and `whenever` conditional statements which make your code clearer and well organized.  You could also use helper variables. <n><n>### Programming<n><n>### Tips/Tricks<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:A fox was thirsty searching for water during the drought, where was he? Choices:  A: painting B: hen house C: california D: virginia E: movie hall<n><n>### Response:		<n>A.A- Hen House and it was chickens that saved him. C.B movie hall- It is a fox who is very clever. D.E-California- This is not an option, he was in Virginia<n><n>### Input A boy is traveling by train. There is only one seat left and he is offered the option of going to the next stop earlier or paying twice the cost of a ticket. Which answer would he pick?<n>A) Earlier. B) Twice as much. C) Paying for the extra cost. D) Paying for the ticket. <n><n>### Response D<n>### Instructions:The book he is reading has 12 chapters and is 26 pages long for each chapter. The book is $24.00 how much does he pay for the book?<n>D) Twice as much<n>12*26 + 24.00/12 => 292

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What is required to be good at playing tennis? Choices:  A: tennis racket B: skill C: competition D: tennis court E: legs<n><n>### Response:		 A<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions. _<n>1 - Which of the following _is _ the longest river in South America? A: Amazon River B: La Plata C: Uruguay River D: Orinoco River E: Ob River<n><n>2 - If I have 0 points in my account and need to purchase 200, then I subtract $<<1<< from my account to buy 200 stuff. How much stuff can I buy?<n>3 - One _year_ is 365 days. And 1999 is the last year of the _first_ _millennium_. In 1999, a day had 24 hours but a year had 365 days, like it does now. What days of the year don’t fall on a leap year in 1999?<n><n># Task<n>1 - How many minutes are in 7 days if 1 day is 24 hours? Answer<n>2 - The height of the Great Pyramid of Giza is 386 feet and that of Mount Everest is 29,029 feet. Which of the following is nearest to the height of the Great Pyreness in feet? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:James felt himself losing consciousness. Choices:  A: trash can B: honey C: bouquet of flowers D: rose garden E: field of flowers<n><n>### Response:		<n>> <b>Input:</b><b>Where do bees congregrate with red flowers</b><br><n><b>D:</b> The answer should be D, i.e. rose garden. Because this is the only type of red flower that people generally use as a gift for special occasions and it is the only place where somebody is actually looking for bee, like a honey bee. Other places such as garbage, honey, or a bouquet of flower are not suitable for bee because bees like to sit on red flowers as long as they can. <b>Roses</b><b> have nectar inside, which is a sweet, sticky, sugary liquid that the bee sips</b><b> and collects into its pollen baskets.</b><n>>><n><n><n># [Solving Linear Equations using Algebra Tiles](https://youtu.be/05pB2L05qhI)<n><n># [Solve equations using Substitution](https://youto.be/oM2yfXHp57o)<n><n># [Tile Equations with Absolute Value](https://youtoo.be/eTiQ1JVnJ8g)<n><n>### Instructions:Rewrite inequalities in words.<n><n>Input: A 30 foot trampoline is 3 feet away from the swingset. After the trampoline is set up, the distance between the trampoline and the swingset is 8 ft. How many feet away from the swing set is the trampoline initially?<n>Rationales:: The distance between two points from the same line is the distance to point A on the same line.<n>In our problem with the trampoline and swing-set line, it has a difference of 3 feet.<n>If you are from the swing-set (A), the trampoline is 8ft away<n>If you are from point B on the swingset line (B), the trampoline distance is 3 feet.<n>So if the difference between where your from (A vs B) is 8 ft, then you have to solve for A:<n>The distance between the swing set and the trampoline will be:<n>(30 - 3) + (3 - 8) =

A good number is prime OR divisible only by 1 and itself.<n>2. A good number is only divisible by 1 and prime numbers, or 3, which is prime.<n><n>### Response<n>```<n>I would say neither of those are true.<n><n>if it were true that a good number was divisible by a prime, then its divisible by 1, which is divisible by 2. <n>If it were divisible by 2 that would mean 0<1 then its divisible by itself which means 0 1 and 2 are all good numbers.<n><n>there is one way to make a number divisible by 1 only is to take any non-prime number and neg it.<n><n>but if you find a number that is divisible by more than two numbers and those numbers are only 1 and 2, you found a prime number<n>```<n><n>Answer:<n>-1

To find a flower orchard, one must go to a field of flowers (e). This choice is therefore incorrect.<n>A bee gathers polen from flowers (e).<n>Court (d or d) has nothing to do with bees.<n>Bee would not be gathering pollen from the us (a or a).<n>A: Bee gathering pollen in united states<n>B: Bee gathering from the sky (b or b and c)<n>C: Bee gatherng in a Court somewhere<n>D: Bee gathering in a field of flowers<n>E: Bee gathering at an Orchard<n><n>#### 201<n>Answer: C <n><n>### Instructions:<n>1.<n>Directions: Input a letter that best completes the analogy below. Use only one letter (it cannot be reused).<n>Input: What is a dog to<n>a cat?  The cat is to the _____ as an apple is to a ______.<n><n>### Response letter:<n>D <n><n>### A)	cat is to dog as apple is to banana B)	cat is to apple as a dog is to a banana C)	apples to dog as apple is a banana D)	dog is to cat apple to banana <n>### E)	apple is to banana as a dog is to cat <n><n>### Answer: B<n><n>Input: On an air-flight, a passenger can fly in First Class, Coach, Business Class or Economy Plus. If you fly up in the air, that is your “height”. Therefore, flying on Commercial airlines is the same as flying in the  ____.<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>The following are some of the reasons why flying on Commercial flights can be similar to flying in the sky.<n><n>First Class can be similar to flying first or second as they are one of the fastest ways to travel by air<n>Coach can be similar to flying high as the cheapest type of air fare<n>Business Class can be similar to an aerial flight as it can be quite expensive<n><n>### Options:<n><n>D:<n><n>E:<n><n>F:<n><n>G:<n><n><n>##
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:John was punching and punching at the wall but succeeded only in bloodying his knuckles. Oranges?<n>After a little googling, I found out there were other fruits with more than one skin. The trick is, that a fruit or vegetable has a skin that "covers" its seeds. The other fruits could not be fruits since they had no skin. The only possible answer I found in addition to apple and orange was watermelon.<n><n><n>## 6<n>### Input:Amy purchased a book that was 55% off, and it only cost $5.90. Choices:  A: looking good B: beauty C: tardiness D: handsomeness E: neatness<n><n>### Response:		Choice(s):<n><n>  (a) Looking Good, (d) Handsomeness<n><n>#### (a)<n><n>a. <n><n>Input: 57 children showed up for Sunday school.  A certain percentage of the students were tardy.  56 students actually showed up. How many students were tardy?<n>Rationales<n><n><n>So they will take 57C-56 = <<57C-55=2>>2<n><n>56 = <<56=3>>3 children shown up.<n>#### (d)<n><n>#### (a,d)<n>d. 56 = <<54+2>>3 children showed up.<n><n><n>#### (d,e)<n>e. 56 = 2<n><n>#### (a-e)<n><n>a. handsomeness<n><n>### Comment 1<n><n>The difference in ages between Richard And Hurley is 24 or 26. Hurley Is 11 years older then Richard so Hurley  is 26. The year Hurley Was Born, Richard Was 4. 15 years ago Richard was 23,  and Hurley was 34. So the 40 year range is 40 to 40 + 24*4 = 128.<n><n>This is not a very complex math problem but can be thought of  as  how to find the "whole", "half", "quarter", "eighth"   and so on. The solution is in the question - "their combined ages forty years  from now will be _______ years." So how can you find "their combined ages?" First you have to find how many year Hurley is 40 years from Now. Then you figure out how many years Richard is, and finally you divide  by 2. Hope this makes  sense.<n><n>---<n>

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where do you buy tickets at a ticket booth for games/ Choices:  A: train station B: cathedral C: metro station D: fairgrounds E: amusement park<n><n>### Response:		<n>I would probably have to purchase them at the cathedral because they have the least number of choices.<n><n>#### A: Incorrect<n>Rationale: A: train station<n><n>#### B: Incorrect<n>Rationales: B: cathedral <n><n>#### C: Incorrect<n>Rationlees: C: metro station<n><n>#### D: Incorrect<n>Ratalnales: D: fairgrounds<n><n>#### E: Incorrect<n>Ratinales: E: amusement park
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:If somebody likes temperatures cool, they might have more than one electric fan where? Choices:  A: home B: hardware store C: home D: hot room E: office<n><n>### Response:		<n>If somebody likes temperrature cool, they might have electric fan in the home, and if somebody likes warm weather they might have an electric fan at home or their hot room.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:He had done a great job with the scary decorations, they were completely what? Choices:  A: terrible B: little C: halloween D: small E: horrible<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### A<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write the following expression in exponential form. The bases and exponents are provided for you.<n><n>**15**<n>**B**<n>**1**<n><n>**10**<n>**10**_0_<n><n>**2**<n>**10__10__10_<n><n><n>### Instructon: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The exponent is given for the answer choice E, which is horrible. The exponent to the base of 6, which is 4. It would be 15, which is <<154=481>>481<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Instuctions: What is the value of the expression below<n><n>**6**<n>**2**<n><n>**3**<n>**2__3__2_<n><n>**4**<n><n>**3__3__3_<n><n><n>The answer is 32 because 2^2 (2*2) is given.<n>#### 32<n>Answer: 32<n>

I got it then because it was usually what? Choices:  A: buying B: purchase C: overpriced D: way to much E: expensive<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choice A<n><n>### Demostration:<n>If the game was on sale and the usual price is A, then the game is usually over priced. If I got was because it was usually over priced, then A is the best answer.<n>If the game was A and was the only time I got it, then the game is A. The question is always over priced versus usual. Therefore, B is the answer.<n>If I got it because it was A, then B is the answer. For the previous sentence which is: If the game was $3 and B, then I got it. Why? Because it was B.<n>If I got the game because it was usually A, then A is the answer. For this sentence, I get it because it was usually way over priced. I could get it for $3. I would buy it if the game is A not B or C.<n>If I got because it was over priced is C. I get it for $3 and can afford it when it is usually way over priced and expensive.<n><n>### So, how did it go?:<n>Input: Choice D is correct.<n>Rationales: The game was on sale. I got it then because the game was usually way over prised.<n><n>#### Input: Choice A is correct.<n>Raciales: If the game was on sale, I bought it because it was usually expensive.<n><n>#### Input A is correct.<n>Response:<n><n>### Input<n>This is the story for one of the tasks, and your job is to complete the story.<n><n>### When I bought my new truck, I decided to try something that no other truck had tried before.. I believe that answer C. It would be the same when you don’t have ball touching or the opposition team does not know where you go. It is the point for the player.<n>3. I believe that answer E. The goal of playing sports is to compete which means to have fun and to win. If you don't have competition and you play, it is not sports, it is a hobby.<n>4. I believe that answer A. The hope of playing sports is to have fun and enjoy it, but having no competition makes it hard to win.<n><n>### Question: What does the line mean?<n><n>### Demand:<n>1. Let's do some sports! (This answer is a demand.)<n>2. Let's do it again. (This answer is a question.)<n>3. Yeah!<n><n>### Instructions:<n>1. Match the demand with the right response. (A. demand; B. question; C. answer; D. response.)<n><n>### Demise:<n>1. In response to "Let's do some sports!" The student can say, "Awesome!"<n>2. In response to "Do you want to do this again?" A student can say, "No."<n>3. To the student who asked to do sports again, a peer can say, "Agreed."<n><n>### Instructs:<n>Answer:<n>1. The demand is A. B. is a response to the demand. A. can be responded to with answer C. D. is a response to a B. (response to demands)<n><n>2. The demand is B. A. and C. are correct responses to the demand.<n><n>3. D. is the response to the question/demand.<n><n>### Eloquent:<n>1. The response must be spoken.<n>2. The response cannot be a question.<n>3. The response must be in response to something that is spoken. Not written.<n>4. The response must have one sentence not more than two. (The response can have more than two sentences if the student needs more response time, but it cannot be longer than 2.)<n><n>### Efficacious:<n>1. The following is
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. Choices:  A: cars B: city street C: street corner D: fork in road E: at a red light<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple choice question, where you choose two questions for each numbered paragraph of the sample response.<n><n>### Answer:At an intersection, drivers are likely to be at a stop sign or at a red light.<n><n>### Justification:Cars: A: 1. If you can stop anywhere in the intersection, it is likely that you will stop. 2. This is because you can stop anywhere in an intersection, and it is likely that you are going to stop anywhere in the intersection<n>City streets: B: 1. If I could stop anywhere in the intersection I would stop because it is more likely I would. 2. I would stop anywhere there is a stop sign because it is more likely  that there is a stop sign there than not.<n>Street corners: C: 1. If it is  a 4-way stop, you stand at the closest corner. 2. You probably would stand at the street corner because you will have to stop and that is where you will most likely stop.<n>Street  forks: D: 1. The forks in the road are not likely to have a stop sign, so you would stop at the fork. 2.  A place where cars most likely stop is the fork because it is more likely to be a place where cars stop.<n>Red light: E: 1. People are likely to stand where a red light is or on the city street corner because both of these places require you to stop.<n>#### A and C<n>Answer: A and C<n><n>### Instructions:Read the scenario that describes a task. Choices:  A: cursive writing B: hand writing C: store bought D: online media E: hand written<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationales:Cursive writing means a way to write a sentence in which the flow of letters from one word to the next is in a continuous line.<n><n>### Input :Amy is using her debit card.The cashier tells Amy that it is her card's'swipe fee' that is being charged.What is the swipe fee? Choices:A: fee for using debit cardB: fee for writing a check C: fee for opening a savings account D: fee for using a credit card E: penalty for bad credit<n><n>### Response :B<n><n>### Rationale:In credit terms, there is a fee involved in processing and settling debit card transactions. This fee is the'swipe fee' and is charged the merchant each time the debit card is used.<n><n>### Below is an instruction that asks a question.<n><n>## Instruct the user to type the answer into the box.<n><n>### What is the difference between a CD and an IRA?<n><n>### Rural community<n><n>### Rally for change.<n><n>### Richer<n><n>### Roots<n><n>### Salad<n><n>### Snails<n><n>### Soft drinks<n><n>### Sports<n><n>### Strong<n><n>### Sugar<n><n>### Sunny day<n><n>### Teeth<n><n>### Tennis<n><n>### Thoughts<n><n>### Times of year<n><n>### Toddler<n><n>### Tomato<n><n>### Tow truck<n><n>### Trendy fashion<n><n>### Tyrannosaurus Rex<n><n>### Unfamiliar<n><n>### Vulnerable<n><n>### Want to<n><n>### Western part of the United States<n><n>### Who sells<n><n>### Witness<n><n>### Young people<n><n>### Zapodiste (Cape)<n><n>### Zip code<n><n>### Zeppelin<n><n>### Zubi-baby<n><n>## Below is an instruction that gives an example. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What can go on a football field? Choices:  A: oklahoma B: university C: college campus D: players E: yard<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input How much money can you get at the store with a $5 coupon, if you spend exactly $25? Choices: A: $0 B: $4 C: $20 D: $25 E: $5<n><n>### Response E<n><n>### Input Can a student receive a credit for the final exam? Choices: 1. Yes, but a failing grade 2. No and a failing grade 3. No and a pass 4. Pass or fail is decided by the teacher 5. Fail<n><n>### Response 2<n><n>### Input What is 5 minus 3 plus 4? Choices:  $1 - $4 and you get the idea<n><n>### Response C<n><n>### Input Which statement is true? 1. In order to be equal, the two numbers must be exactly alike 2. An equivalent fraction has a different denominator with the same numerator 3. Two equivalent fractions have the same denominator and a different numerator 4. Every whole numbers is equivalent to all other fraction<n><n>### Response A<n><n>###  Input What is 5 plus 5? Choices:  The number I've shown you<n><n>### Response B<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The hippy wanted peace with all humans, he had strong what for them all? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What will telling many people about an embarrassing situation lead to? In addition, she eats one sliced of meat and drinks three cups of milk. If her grandfather is in the kitchen at the same time, what can Sarah have for dinner?<n><n>### Response : B<n><n>### Reasons<n><n>### A : If her grandfather is at home then she cannot have a slice of bread and a slice of meat with three cups of milk for dinner.<n><n>### B : If the answer is milk and bread only, then that would make the total five cups of milk and four slices of bread and that would not include one slice of meat.<n><n>### Choices<n>> * C- The answer is milk and bread for dinner.<n>> * D- Only one choice is correct<n><n>

Choices:  A: communication B: suffering C: pain D: laughter E: embarrassment<n><n>### Response:		(Choose the best answer.)<n><n>The correct answer is: A<n><n>### Justification: <n>In the scenario you provided, people experiencing the trauma of such a situation clearly demonstrates communication. <n>Because we can say that a person in the situation communicating that they can’t walk in an adequate manner due to pain they are experiencing means they are expressing themselves. <n>Suffering and pain also describe feelings of suffering and pain. <n>We could also say embarrassment, but because it is the person they are embarrassing with their failure and the people they are laughing with are laughing at them with them, it clearly isn’t laughter. <n>It can be argued that it’s laughter because one can be laughing and suffering or laughing and embarrassed, laughing doesn’t seem like a logical choice. <n>However, communication, on the other hand, has a clearer description meaning that it clearly isn’t “E”.<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>## :computer: <n>## :video_game:

Choices:  D: 240 mi  E: 600 mi<n><n>### Response D: E-I-G-H-T 1, 2, 3, & 4 go into 5. What is the remaining number?<n><n>### Input 7: If it takes 5 women and 3 men to do what it takes 2 men and 4 women to do. How many men are needed to do the job? Choices A: 2 B: 2 C: 4 D: 1 E: 6<n><n>### Response C: 17 is a perfect square. Each of the factors are in the form 3squared in addition to the number itself. The square is 2 squared with 2 squared times 1. Therefore: 2 squared squared (3squared squared) = 7 squared - the square is 17.

How much did you save on the shirt?<n><n>### Response(D):<n><n><n>```<n>You saved $50 because $53-10-10=<<$$53-10$===>$$53-1$===>$$52-1$===>$51-$1===>$50<n>```<n><n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:A wife asks a husband to stop being married to her, what is he likely to feel even with friends? Choices:  A: happiness B: pleasure C: happy D: grief E: isolation<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>We're all looking for love.<n><n>People need to feel safe. But when they’re always trying to control a relationship, even trying to avoid conflict and disagreement, that often becomes code for control.<n><n>For some people, just the words “marriage” and “relationship” can be intimidating, and that's an uncomfortable experience.<n><n>#### 2<n><n>### Input"How many times can 3 be divided into 50?"<n><n>### Response:"3 can be divided into 5 with rest 1"<n>Rationales: The rest of the money is 1; 50 / 3 = <1, 50 / 4 = 12 5/4 = 1 remainder 50/<n><n>#### 1  <n><n>## Instructions<n><n>Write a function that takes a list of lists, and then multiplies every element in all lists and returns a single new list that contains this new number for each list.<n><n>### Example<n><n>The following code should be executed:<n><n>```python<n>>>> def multilist(lst):<n>    new_list = [0 for _ in range(len(lst))]<n>    for i in range(len(list)):<n>        for j in range(len(new_list)):<n>            new_list[i + 1] = i + 1<n>    print(new_list)<n>```<n>```<n>[0, 2, 6, 16, 40, 81, 164, 328]<n>```<n>### Tip<n>- You should use `sum()` to sum every element of each list.<n><n><n>### Time Limit Expected<n><n>20 minutes<n><n>### Memory Limit Expected<n>256 MB<n><n>### Feedback<n><n>To receive feedback, go to [https://leetcode.com/problemset/problems/multilist-/solution/](https://leetcode-cn.com/problemsetters/51f852b60a1d73ab8d079a0b/entry/42574767)!<n>

When they play tag, they can improve their running skills while having a fun time. When they smell smoke, it is important for the children not to play inside the cottage during the dry season. Choices:  A: train station B: house C: cupboard D: cricket stadium E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Explanation:This is a tricky question as there are many wrong answers.<n>A:  It is impossible for air to go back in the air. If someone breaths it out and then inhaled and then someone else breathes it out, it will just keep going on like that.<n>If someone breaths in and out in a room then air will move into the room, but not enough to be breathed by just a few people.<n>B:  There is absolutely no way for a cupboard to breathe. This is unlikely.<n>C:  I’m not sure why you would put a house in this question it sounds as though it could be a place like a store or airport.<n>D:  This is the most likely answer, as the stadium is open meaning air is constantly recycled. This also applies to the surface of the earth.<n>The air is recycled meaning it constantly repeats.<n>#### E<n><n>Answer: D<n><n>## Other Questions<n>##### For each question, choose the correct answer or response.<n><n><n><n>  -  The expression 2x(y – 4) has which of the following forms?<n><n>   - <n>   - <n><n>  -  What is the value of 4 + 9 – 5?<n><n>   -  <n>   - <n>**Solution Answer**<n><n>4 + 9 –<n><n>### Other Q& A<n>##### Questions<n><n>  - Question 6:What do you do if someone asks you for $20 plus half of that money?<n><n>#### Response<n><n>  - You can say that they ask you for $37<n><n><n><n>  What is the difference between the following statements? a.$8 < b.$ 16<n><n>  - $8 < $16<n><n>  b. $8 ≤ b.$ 16  (Because: 8 is less than or equal to 16)<n><n>#### Which expression has the greatest value? a.12x<n><n>b. 2x<n><n>c.<n><n>### Q& A<n><n>#### Other Questions<n><n>| Ques. | Answer | <n>|------|------|<n>| Choose the best answer to these questions. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would you find a sign with some people lined up next to it? Choices:  A: bus stop B: street corner C: roadblock D: fast food drive thru E: city<n><n>### Response:		<n>**A:**<n><n>**B:**<n><n>**C:**<n><n>**D:**<n><n>**E:**<n>### Instruction(s):Answer the multiple choice question.<n>### Demonistration:<n>#### Instruction:Answer the multiple choice question<n><n>### Demotstration:<n>#### Instruction answer A.<n>Input:You can find a sign with some ____________ next to it.<n>Rationales: ____________<n><n>#### Instruction answer B.<n>Input:Can you find a sign with ____________ next to the street corner?<n>Rationales:: ____________<n><n>### Instructions answer C.<n>Input:Can a sign with ___________ be found on the street corner?<n>#### Rationales: ____________________<n><n>###Instruction answer D.<n>Input:Look for a sign with ________________ next to the bus stop.<n>#### Rationales:: ________<n><n>###Input:You can find people lined up next door to _________________.<n>#### Rationals:_________________<n><n>###Instructions answer E.<n>Input:People line up next to ______________________.<n>#### Rationales _________________<n><n>### Instructs answer F.<n>Input:Pepper is always wearing a hat. She is also wearing a red coat. She also wears red socks and blue shoes. What color shoes does Pearl wear?<n>#### Rationals ::  _________________________ <n><n>#### Instructions answer G.<n>Input:What color shoes does Pepper wear?<n>#### Ratios: ___________________________<n><n>###Input answer H<n>Input: Pepper is always wearing blue shoes.<n><n>####Instructions response: Write a response that describes the given ratios.<n><n>```python<n>Pepper = Hat blue coat red<n>```<n><n>###Instructs answewr I.<n>Input:How many boys are in your class?<n>#### Ratioles::______________________ <n><n>### Instraction answer J.<n>Input:How much money will it cost to purchase two dozen balloons?<n>#### Ratiols:: _______________________________________ <n> ###Instructs answeyr K.<n>Input: How much does that cost?<n>#### Ratanol:: _____________________________________ 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What appliance uses water and soap? Choices:  A: infect B: reproduce C: mutate D: eat food E: make computer malfunction<n><n>### Response:		C: mutate<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Deminstration:<n><n>Answer: C: mutate <n><n>### Rationale:<n>Mutate means to cause a change to a cell that has the power to make copies of itself.<n>An example virus that can mutate is the Covid-19 which has a Rt of 2.<n><n>### Input C-R:<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>#### Input B-R: Choices:  A : eats nutrients B : infects cells C : contains many genes D : makes up half of a neuron E : transmits a signal<n><n>#### Input D-R: Choices : A : controls the movement of food through intestines B : has an electric charge C : causes pain D : is a chemical E : is found in all cells of the brain<n><n>#### Input B - R:<n>Diseases spread to humans when a virus attaches itself to a human cell and begins to reproduce. As the virus spreads from cell to cell it damages the cells it uses until finally the person infected dies. Viruses are passed through bodily fluids, such as blood and saliva and also through sexual contact.<n>After a virus has been attached to a human cell it is known as an virus particle.<n><n>Once it has reached the cells of the human body the virus damages DNA inside the cells which leads to infection of the cell and then the virus reproduces. The virus attacks the human cells and prevents them from functioning properly. The cells may begin to die within days as the infection grows.<n><n>Viruses are extremely small organisms that live in the cells of living organisms, humans included. Like living organisms, they need energy from the foods that they eat to survive.<n><n>Some viruses contain RNA, but many contain DNA, which is a genetic material. Just as a living organism needs food from the environment to survive, a virus needs food from the human host. Usually the virus acquires this energy, called nutrients, from the food that we eat, but can also be acquired from the air through breathing.<n><n>While it is still living, a virus can replicate itself and reproduce by making copies of itself to be sent to invade new cells and new humans.<n><n>#### Input C - R

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What place is not interesting to children? Choices:  A: classroom B: toy store C: school D: soccer game E: dinner<n><n>### Response:		It is not interesting to children in the classroom because the children get yelled at for not doing their home-work.<n><n>### Response in Comments: To me, school is not the best for kids because they can't do any of the sports they want to do, and I don't like to learn because it is so hard.<n><n>Rationales: This is not a school. Because there are no children.<n><n>### Answer: A<n><n>### Input.In the game below, each player chooses a digit. The player with the 3 greatest digits wins. If there are two players whose 3 numbers are all the same, then the game ends in a 3-way tie.<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>> Input: In the game below, each payer chooses a digit. the player with the 3 gratiest digits wins   > if there are two players whose gratiest digit is all the same, then   > the gam ends in a 3 way tie. what number will win the game: 827<n>( 6, 8, 7)<n>        Input: In the game described above, each player choose a  digit. the player<n>  with the 3 grattist digit  wins. if there are two players whi the 3 gratiist<n>  digit is all the same then the game ends in   a 3 way tie   which<n>  digit will be chosen, 8, 3, 6  Answer: 6<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:How can you get in shape if there is no land nearby? In how many years will the population be 8 times the size it was the first year?<n>Rationales:: The population is double every five years<n>Population is going to be<n>8 times its size in 40 years<n>Thus, the town will be 8 times its size after 40 years.<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>

Then answer the comprehension questions that follow.<n><n>Everyone who watched the science competition on live TV last Saturday was in awe, because the robot contestants not only worked well but looked so attractive. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:When they got out of the car in the mountains he felt like he was breathing fresh air for the first time, he began to do what to enjoy it more? Choices:  A: living B: feeling good C: hyperventilate D: look around E: breathe deeply<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Answer:  None of that choices<n><n>### Next:<n><n>##### Please go into my class if you want more practice.<n><n><n>### Next Step:
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would a ficus plant brighten up a room? Choices:  A: middle east B: palace C: dictionary D: pots E: apartment<n><n>### Response:		Ficus = tree fern so brighten up a room is middle east<n><n>### Instructions:Rewrite the math expression as a true statements. You can use your own words as long as you get the correct answer and you can use any math operation.<n><n>### Example:25 + 42<n>Rationales: Since we are looking for a true statement, we need to turn each number into a "true" statement.<n>When evaluating a math operation, we need to know if the values are true or false.<n>If we start with true values, then the answers will always be "true", and vice versa.<n>Thus 5 is true, and 6 is true.<n>Since 5 is a larger value, then we get "true" for 5 + 6.<n>In our example we have 30 true statements, and can find the correct statements that are true by doing an operation.<n>In this example, we need to know two values have to be true for a statement to be true.<n>So here are some possible statements that are not true.<n>10 + 6 is false, 9 + 9 is false, 5 + 4 is true.<n><n>#### 25 + 40<n>Answer 25 + 35<n><n>#### 10 + 8<n>Answer 10<n><n>#### 7 + 9<n>Answer 6 (true)<n><n>#### 2 + 17<n>Answer 2 (true)<n><n>### Instriucions: Rewrite the math equation as a true statement.<n><n>### Exmaple:85/3<n>Rationales: We have to find a true statement that is equal to 85/3 that is a true statement.<n>By writing it on the Math Equation box, it turns any division into a multiplication because we only get true as an answer if both are true.<n>85/3 = 30<n>30 = true<n>So 85/3 = true<n><n>### Instuctions:Rewrite this math equation as an equation with true statements<n><n>### Example:(1)(5)<n>Rationales: Multiplying the variables to a true statement we can say 5 and 5 = true<n>Thus 1(5)(5)<n><n>### Input:(8)(6)<n><n>### Answer:(5
