Expected Outcome: After attempting the exercise, the users/students will be  able to understand  multipe choice questions using a binary tree approach. <n><n>### Instructor’s note: <n><n><n># 0025/Finding A Missing Number Challenge<n><n>* Note: This challenge requires multiple if statements that determine which value to return. Including the correct missing input.<n><n>### Background<n><n>This challenge should be easy for the coder to execute. If they struggle then they did not review the previous challenges and are not ready to take this challenge.<n><n>### Challenge<n>```<n>A. In the following sequence, what is the last missing number?<n><n>1. 9<n>2. 9, 10, 11, 5,?<n>3. 9, 26, 23, 19, 4,?, 15, 13, 17, 14 and 12<n>```<n><n>1. If statement solution<n>2. if statement solution2<n>3.<n><n>### Expected Learning Outcomes<n>The students should be able to identify the multiple if statements required in finding the missing number. The students should be able to determine the correct sequence of values.<n><n><n># 18/Finding Missing Number Challenge<n>```<n>A18. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What does one chop us a grape for? Choices:  A: fresh fruit B: wine press C: fruit basket D: fruit cocktail E: picnic basket<n><n>### Response:		The answer is B, as grape is a fruit and it can be pressed and fermented to make wine.<n><n>Answer: Wine Press<n><n>### Input<n>Input: Sally bought some fresh groceries for $50 and 11 of bananas for $8 a bunch. How much was the total she spent?<n>Rationales:: She bought 6 bananas for $50 - 11 bananas for $8 = <<$50-11*8=6>>6 bananas.<n>The total she spent was $50+6 = <<50+6=56>>56<n>#### 56<n>Answer: $56<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input: Sally walked to the store to buy a pack of chocolate with 25% sugar. She spent $2.50 and there was.25% sugar. How much did she spend for all of the sugar.<n><n>Input: What does one chop us an avocado for? Choices: A: taco salad B: hamburger C: burger D: fish E: cucumber salad<n><n>### Rationales: Her pack of candy had.25% sugar<n>Sugar is sold by weight<n>So how much is 500 grams of sugar with.25% sugar?<n>.25 x 500 = 125 grams<n>Since she has a pack with 25% of sugar, the whole pack of candy will have 125g of sugar.<n><n>Input1: 3 people go to a fast food place as a party of three. 1 order of chicken, 1 order of fries, and 1 large diet coke. 2 people split an order of chicken, the 2nd person orders a large diet. What 1 person ordered? What diet did Person 2 get?<n><n>Input2: A person can order a variety of food at a fast food place - 28 food options. When we go as a party of 5, if we share, what could we have? (3 different food orders)<n><n>### RESPONSE  : Person 1 ordered fries and a diet <n><n>### Question : When we go as a Party of six, what is the
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:James was a student who had a report that is due tomorrow.  Where might he spend most of his time today? Choices:  A: university B: college class C: class room D: classroom E: library<n><n>### Response:		<n>The Student will prefer to spend most of his time in the college class.<n><n>### Input<n>Gregory needs to borrow 20 dollars to get his car repaired. He already has 25 in his wallet. Which is the smaller number: his wallet’s contents or the money he needs to borrow? Choice A: His wallet’s contents choice B: The money needed to borrow C: The two together choice D: None of the above<n><n>### Demostration<n>If Gregory has 20 and requires 20 he has no money<n>If Gregory has 50 and requires 21 he has 30<n><n>if Gregory has 21 and requires 30 he has 26<n>if Gregory 26 and requires 30 so he needs to borrow 3<n><n>### Answer<n>C<n><n>### Input A: If it takes 5 weeks to fill a pool of water how many gallons of water are needed? Choice A: 10 Choice B: 5 Choice C: 20 Choice D 15<n><n>#### 20<n>#### 10<n>#### 15<n>Answer: 10<n><n><n>### Input B: When the pool is full how much water does it take? Choice A: it takes 5 gallons to fill a pool Choice B : 105 Choice C : 510 Choice D : No pool can be made to hold more than 100 gallons of water<n><n>### Answer C<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:James went to the best steakhouse outside of the South.  Where is James? Choices:  A: dairy farm B: texas C: building D: michigan E: florida<n><n>### Response:		F<n><n>### Justification<n><n>### Input :<n>Steakhouse is something you go to eat, dairy farm is where you get dairy.<n><n>### Output<n>A: dairy farm B Texas C: building D: Michigan E: Florida<n><n>### Output justification<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration:Input: The number of girls in the class is 35. If you were to subtract the number of girls that speak Spanish from the number of girls in the school, what is the difference?<n>RationalesWhen we subtract, the difference is the difference. <n>#### 31<n>Answer: 31<n><n>### Instructor: Answer the following multiple-choice questions.<n><n>## Demstration: Input: A class of 24 students takes the standardized math test. Three fourths of the students scored 75% or higher. Which of the following numbers is equivalent to 7?<n><n>Rationales : The sum of a set equals the total of the set.  When you multiply any number you have to make sure that you have enough numbers to cancel each other that is why when you multiply you have to do so with odds and not even numbers. <n>When we canceled the even numbers such as 10,2,4 out of the equation the one remaining odd number is 12.<n>#### 12/4 = 3<n><n>##Justification:<n>When we cancele the even numbers like 10,2 and 4 out of the equation. The one remaining odd number is **12/4 =3** the number that represents the math problem as **7**. <n><n>### Instinct: Answer the following multiple choice problem.Which of the given numbers is closest to 30<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Rationales: You have 11/9 = 1 1/9 = 5/9 = 3 in a ratios.<n>You have 5/9 = **2**<n>you go from big number to small numbers or **3** to find the answer.<n>1/9 = 0.11111...<n>0.88888...<n>0....<n>So the answer is 0.5<n>#### 0

Choices:  A: friendship B: aggression C: defeat D: winning or losing E: sweat<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is 'E'.<n><n>### Instructions:A new video game console is released with two versions: a 16 bit and an 8 bit. The 16 bit had twice as much storage space. In order to take advantage of the storage space, the creator of the video game would have to update each one of the games to run on the new system. However, the creator of this game decided that the 8 bit version of the game wasn't worth the additional memory and only made updates to the 16 bit game. There were only two games, each of which were $40. If they were $40 and they sold 6 times as many 16-bit games as the 8-bit games, what are the sales?<n>Rationales:(16 bit games / 8 bit games)*$40 = <<16/8*40=+6>>6 times more 16-bit sales<n>$240 for 16 bit games, and $40 for 8 bit games<n><n>#### 0<n>Answer: None<n><n>### Input and Instructions:Sue loves playing the lottery. She decides to buy ten lottery tickets each day. Three out of those ten tickets will be discarded, or will have 0 value. If she spends $30 a day on tickets, and the tickets all have the same value, then how much does she spend in total?<n><n>### Response and Rationales:She is left with an average ticket cost of 5 dollars.<n><n>$30 divided by 30 is.1<n>So the average cost is $5*(1/.1)=<<5*(.1)>=50$<n>So the total is 50<n>#### 0.051<n>Answer: 0.5<n><n>Input: A car was damaged and a repair person was called in to fix it. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. Choices:  A: hunt B: pay merchants with money C: mail orders D: spend money E: demand satisfaction<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: hunt<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Letters h, a, and t are the digraphs for the sound [h] and the letter s is a consonant. By writing each of the words without repetitions by using letters, we can eliminate the option that is not a real English word from possible answers.<n><n>The word "shop" can be written with letters h, a, and p or t, but we can eliminate the word "shop" from the possible answer choices because the word "shop" is not in the instruction.<n><n>The options "shop" and "price" can be written with the letters "hunt" or "mail," but we can eliminate the option "shop" from among the possible answers because the word "shop," as shown above, is not in the instruction text.<n><n>The word that has one of the required letters, as well as the letters from the consonant digraphs shown above and the phonetic digraph, as shown above, is the word "hunt."<n><n>#### hunt<n>Answer: hunt<n><n><n>### Acknowledgment:<n>This task was cited from [Instructional Design for Online Tutorials](/instructional-design-for-online-tutorials) (2014)<n><n>Acknowledgment:<n>https://goo.gl/Fzc4HX

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What is a useful activity when experiencing loneliness? Choices:  A: meet people B: meet friend C: make people laugh D: socialize E: liquor<n><n>### Response:		A: B<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Rationale: C and E are negative activities. Loneliness is painful and it is very important to find out how to handle it in a healthy way. Meeting new people can help distract you from experiencing loneliness. Also, laughing is known to be very attractive. You could make people laugh and also become friends.<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>### Input<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>### Instuction:Answer the following multiple choices question.<n><n>## Input: If x represents a two-digit number and if y represents a three-digit number, how many different 3-digit numbers is x + y?<n>## <n><n>## Rationale:<n><n>#### Instruction:A company plans to increase sales by 30 percent. Last year, the total sales were $5000.00. What will be the total sales this year?<n><n>## <n>## Rationale<n><n>## Instructions<n><n>## Input:Write a story that includes at least 10 sentences.<n><n>## <n><n># Projects<n># 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What is KFC who serves chicken? Choices:  A: fast food restaurant B: plate C: bowl D: freezer E: oven<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### C<n>Answer: <n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a response that correctly completes the request or instruction.<n><n>### Input 1<n>Write a function named multiplyTwoNumbers(n1,n2) that first accepts two number as input arguments. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What prevents someone from getting sleep at night? So you will need 15 g or 1 serving snack to make energy for your body to use
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where do you buy treats for kids over a counter? Choices:  A: candy store B: butcher shop C: kitchen D: auto repair shop E: post office<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is A: candy store, because: A: candy store<n>##### <n>Answer: A<n><n>![](https://imgur.com/wq8bX6a.png)<n>Input: What do you buy for 60 cents in a butcher shop? Choices: A: turkey drumsticks B: chickens C: beef stew D: ground turkey E: hamburger E: none of the other answers<n><n>### Response<n>The correct answer is [A]: turkey drumsticks, because: A: turkey<n>#####<n>Answer: A<n>

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where could you find a laundry room that is only used by staff? Choices:  A: house B: hotel C: green house D: college E: dorm<n><n>### Response:		Because a dorm is a place where students live, they must have laundry facilities. There must be dorms/colleges on a college campus. Therefore, the answer is D: college.<n><n>### Input<n><n>A. A laundromat is open 24 hours a day, is equipped with coin operated washers and dryers, charges customers, and offers no other services.<n>B. A laundry room is part of an office complex and only open during office hours. It offers only one washer and one dryer and is also only used by staff of the office complex.<n>C. A laundry services provides wash, dry, and fold services and is available for both residential and residential customers. Their rates are higher than the laundromat listed in part A.<n>D. A laundry is just a room that has washing machines and dryers inside and provides services on site.<n>E. A guest laundry is found on the first floor of a hotel and is open 4 hours per day.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Because only employees use the laundry room, it is clearly part of an office complex. In addition, it is not 24 hours. Therefore, it is not a laundromat and the answer is B.<n><n>### Answer:<n>B. Answer: Only the employee section.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Because only employees can use it, the only people using it is people using the office complex. That means it is an employee section.<n><n>

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The artist didn't use many colors to capture the view, he was famous for his very plain what? Choices:  A: ghost town B: third world country C: human body D: rug E: hospital<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Instructions: Choose the correct answer choice from the given choices.<n><n>### Example: The car's top speed is 125 mph.<n><n>### Answer: <<125 mph>>125 mph<n><n>### Demotivation: Input: The car's speed is 65 mph.<n>Rationales: 65 mph < 125 m.ph, but >= 0 mph<n>65 mph > 25 m.ph<n>65 m.ph < 25 mph<n>65.00 < 25.00<n><n>### Demo:<n>Answer: <<125>>125<n><n>### Demo Answer : The car's top distance is 15 miles.<n><n>### Demo Rationale: 125 m/ph x x = 15 Miles.<n><n>### Input  : 3 + 2<n><n>### Demo answer: <<3+2>>3 + 2<n>### Input : If 3 ≥ x.<n>### Demo answer : If 3 ≤ <<3<=>>3<n><n>### Reteaching: Input : 3 +<n><n>### Demo : 2 + 3 = ¶<n><n>#### 31 and $59<n>Answer:<n><n><n>### Input : -90/4 < (x - 2) / x < 60/4 or {70/4} is true and true < (x-2) / x < false<n><n>### Demo and Rationale:<n><n>If False, x > (x - 2)/x<n><n>If True,  -90/4 > (x-2)/x > 60/4<n><n>### Input<n>- 70/4 is true.<n><n>### Output<n><n>If False, {(x-2)/x} < 70/4<n><n>If True, ((x - 2)/  x) < 70/ 4<n><n>### Rationale:<n>750/4 < (5-2)/5 and 3 < (x - 1)/x<n><n>### Demo<n><n>If False, [(6-1) /6]<5/4<n><n>If Not False

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. Choices:  A: soccer game B: fairgrounds C: movie theatre D: countryside E: state park<n><n>### Response:		A - Since there is popcorn and cotton candy on ground - there is a soccer game likely.<n><n>### Input 2: A person is looking for stamps. He notices he is at Post Office lobby and there is stamp collecting group there. What does he make of it?<n> <n>### Demo: He will make his/her own stamp collection now as there are other people doing it.<n><n>### Answer: A<n><n>### Input : 9 of them are men and one is a woman.<n>How many different groups of 4 could be made.<n><n>### Demo: 9C4 <n><n>### Answer : 9-1 =8C4<n><n>### Input<n>How many 8-letter words can you make from "CAT" and "HAT"<n><n>### Demo<n><n>There are 3 possible 8-letter words you can make - CAT, CATH, and CATHER <n><n>### Rationale<n>First count how many words can you make from one word. In this case there are two. CAT - you can make: CAT CATHER CATH  and for a total  of 3 8-letter words using CAT<n><n>Now see the number of ways you can combine the words CAT and CATHER, where you will get 3 words but the CATHER word is double counted. So the total number of ways is 3 - 1/x= 2<n> <n>You can then write this formula for 8C4, 8*8*8*8.<n><n>### Rational:<n>First count how many ways words can be made from a string. In this case 4.<n>Next, see the number of ways a string can be combined with all other combinations of strings. In this case 8*8*4*3.<n>Then, you can write the formula to calculate 8C4. There are 8 different ways to choose a string and then there are 4 different ways to arrange them.<n><n>### Solution<n>8C4 solution of a word is:<n><n>8! * (3!/2!) * (2! * 6!) * (3! * 2!)<n><n><n>Total word solution will remain  8 * 3!/2! * 6! * 3! / 2!

If you began driving from Denver and at the same time the train begins to move, in what city will you be exactly one-third of the way through your drive?<n><n>### Rationales:<n>To get one-third we divide it by 3 which is <1/3= <<1/3=0.333>>0.333 or 1/3 is 0.333<n>Our starting point is the city we started the drive from and we are going to the city we are one-third of the ways into our drive.  So our next town is <city/3 =<<city/3=0.666>>0.666>.  Then when we get to Los Angeles, 0.334 of the drive was gone, so multiply it by 40<0.666*40=<<0.66640=264>>264 miles.  Then + <0.334 x Los Angeles> <264=L.A.-0.334*L.A.=<<-116>>-116> total mileage to Los Angeles from Denver, which we will find in our google maps or <google maps 264+-116=<<264-116=148>>148.<n><n>### Answer:<n>**Distance:**   <148 miles>  <n>**Description:**   The town of Parker, CO is <148 miles or approx 2.5 hrs> away from Los Angeles, CA<n><n>### [https://learn.freecodecamp.org/en/grant/6df

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What has highly criticized security? Choices:  A: university B: concert C: home D: terminal E: airport<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input(s):<n>1. A group of friends are hiking to a waterfall. They found a river, which leads them to the waterfall. They found some pliers with a carabiner on it, which allowed them to travel safely but also they get to know how to get back home from the waterfall.<n><n>2. A group of 6 friends met together at dinner. They all have the same problem with their car, and they decided to get together at dinner and share their experiences about fixing their car.<n><n>3. A man got in trouble and need to get to a lawyer. The only bus is leaving at noon, and the lawyer's office is only ten minutes away.<n><n>4. A group of 4 friends met a bunch of people who decided to go to a movie. Since so many people were gathering together to see a movie, a ticket becomes very expensive.<n><n>### Output (s):<n><n>#### 40  <n><n>Output: Each member of a group was given $4 for food. Each person was also given 20% extra for an ice cream, but this time, each person decided to buy extra tickets for everyone in the group. If each person took away $20 from their initial amount, how much will each person be left with?<n><n>#### 1000  <n><n>Output (multiple choice): You found a box of cookies on sale that was originally $9.99. It was one bag of cookies that was 20% less than the original amount. You want to buy this to share. How many bags of cookies do you need? <n><n>#### 4  <n><n>Output: Your mom left you $65 and asked how much you would need. You will be giving away $45 to other people, so you need to find how much you would need to be left with to give to everyone else.<n><n>#### -30<n><n>Output: For Halloween, the kids decided to sell candy to all the school bus passengers. They had $100 initially, and they used $25 to rent extra candy tubs. They put $60 toward the bus passes, and spent $15 on themselves. How much did each child end up with?<n><n>#### -25  <n><n>Output: There were 3 girls who were all sharing a bag of pret

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:A person is putting on makeup, what is their likely goal? Choices:  A: feel pleasure B: look attractive C: compliments D: interesting experiences E: joy<n><n>### Response:		<n>I think that the person's likely goal would be to feel pleasure. The person is putting on make up after all, which means they are hoping to feel attractive at the end.<n><n>#### Choice:A<n><n>***<n><n>### Instuction:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Input: The square root of a number is ____. ____. ____, and is also called ____.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Square root means square to the root.<n>The square root of a number means ____.<n><n>

Your account is now set to negative $12. What is your new checking balance?<n><n>The answer can be found to be:<<0>>$0. Which is the case because your bank had negative $12 in your account, which would result in $ - 12. Since your account was set negative, it is still positive $12, and this means your account is now 0, or <<0>>$0.<n><n>### Easy-hard:<n>You have a 10-digit number, where each digit is between 0 and 9. When you add two of these digits, the sum of the digits is between 3 and 9.<n><n>If you then subtract 64 from this new sum, what is the lowest remaining digit?<n><n>Rationales:<n>If you are adding two digits, a sum of 10 would occur. (2 digits are added, and the sum is 10)<n><n>If subtracting 64 from 10 does NOT result in a carry over digit, the digit that's left would be the answer. <<1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9,+>>5-64=0<n><n>#### 0<n>The answer is 0<n><n>### Effort:<n>Write a program that will allow you to check to see whether two numbers are equal.<n><n>### Solution:<n>Create a program that accepts an integer, and one integer that will be checked against it, and also returns a TRUE value if they match and FALSE otherwise.<n><n>`Enter two numbers and choose if true or false.`<n>`number`<n><n>`equal?`<n><n><n>```<n>num1 = gets.chomp<n>num2 = gets.chomp if num1!= num2<n>bool = num1 == num2? true : false<n>```<n><n>### Eager:<n>Create methods that will implement powers of 2. The first team scored 21 points in the first half, while the opponent's team scored 7 points. In which half was the first team able to gain more points?<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>In the first half team gaining more points while in first team score 21points and second team score 21<n>points.<n><n>The second option is half the second of second was played because in this half scored 21 points and second team score 7 points. On his way there, he met up with a girl who was going the opposite direction for a total of 4 hours. Then, he traveled for 3 hours from another girl who was walking 6 hours a day in the same direction. He left with a girl who was traveling in the opposite direction. They walked at a speed of 10 hours / day. They met up and had a total speed of 9 hours / day. How many total hours did it take for him to get there?<n><n><n>### RATIONES :<n>First option is that when he walk to the girl for 4 hours it take 8 hours total<n><n>Second option that he left to another girl and walk 6 hours that total take 14 hours.<n><n>Third option that he meet up the girl and walk for 9 hours that total take 23 hours.<n><n>Total 8+14+23=<<14+23+8=55>>55 hours total when he traveled<n><n>#### 55<n>Answer = 55<n><n>### Bonuses Question 2.<n><n>A boy goes up to a friend and gives her 22 flowers. How many gallons of liquid is contained in a 45-gallon drum?<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input and Response: A 4-foot tall man weighs 350 pounds. How much does a 6 ½-foot tall woman weigh who weighs 400 pounds?<n><n>### Instructor's Note: This one has 2 possible solutions, both of which show correct arithmetic.<n><n>#### The man weighs 5 times more than his height in feet.<n>A = 350<n>B = 400<n>B/A = 400/350 = 1.1 <<1.1==1.1>>1.1x = <<1.1x=1.11>>1.11x = <<1-1.1=0.9>>1.9x = <<1.9x=1.90>>1.90x = <<1.8-1.90=0.1>>0.1 = <<0.2>><n><n>#### Convert to metric: He weighs 45 kg more than his height in meters.<n>A = 167.60<n>B = 185.50<n>A + B = 1672.40<n>185.5 - 167.2 = 18.30 <<18.30==18.30>>18.30 >> A = 185 - 168 <<185-168=16>>16<n>___<n>___<n><Coding_Question><n><n><n><n><n><n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would you find isopropol alcohol and safety glasses? Choices:  A: pub B: restaurants C: in a park D: supermarket E: chemistry lab<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### <n><n>###

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where can you get in shape and drink at a juice bar? If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where was the apple tree said to contain something forbidden? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Billy's mother tripped over a stuffed animal. The concept is understanding that you divide a price by 4 to make an item half the price**<n><n>**Explanation:**<n>We understand that you half the price by simply using "x" for half, so the price should be half the price and not.5.

Choices:  A: being ordered B: less confusion C: boredom D: standing in line E: have to wait for<n><n>### Response:		E - Have to wait for.<n>### Instruction 2:<n>### Demonstraion:<n>Input:The number of years for which you should use a calendar is 0 to 999 years ahead.<n>Rationales: The years from 0 to 9 are 0 to 10 in the 10th year ahead.<n>### Answer: <n>```<n>#!/bin/bash<n><n>read -p "Input your month: " month<n>month=$REPLY<n><n>count=0<n>n=0<n><n>year=0<n>decades=(0, 1, 2,.., 4)<n><n>while [[ $count -le $month ]]<n>do<n>    year=$(( $year + 1 ))<n>    if [ $((year % 400)) -gt 0 ]<n>    then<n>        n=$((year % 10))<n>    else<n>        n=$(((year % 10) -10))<n>    fi<n><n>    if [ $n -lt 10 ]; then<n>    for i in ${decades[@]}<n>    do<n>        if ((i<$n)); then<n>            n=$(((n/10)*10))<n>        fi<n>    done<n>    <n>    count=$((count + 1))<n>done<n><n>year=$(($year+1))<n>echo "Hello! $(($year)) is your next birthday!"<n><n>```<n>

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What do you feel from playing football? Choices:  A: exhilaration B: pain C: death D: getting hurt E: get hurt<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Choice is C "getting hurt".<n><n>### Input1:<n>How tall is Ben? Choices: A: 5 feet tall B: 5'2'' C: 5'3'' D: 5'4''<n><n>### Response1:<n>C<n><n>#### 5' 3 ½''<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Choose the letter of each option you feel is the best answer.<n><n>### Choice:<n>A. I like A so much.<n>B. I like C so much.<n>C. I like D so much.<n>D. I like C and D.<n>E. I like E.<n><n>### Expectation1:Therefore it should be (a).<n><n>### Input2:<n>You are allowed 3 lunch breaks per day. If you were to choose A, you must get 2 lunch breaks in a row during the course of the day. On the other hand, you can select B, and take only one lunch break a day. The difference between taking one lunch break and taking two is $3. Which lunch break(s) is best for you?(1 for B, 2 for A)<n><n>### ExpectedResult2:Therefore expected result should be 1.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Who does the government help with schools? Choices:  A: school children B: parents C: get money D: require to pay taxes E: take money<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input:"What has seven legs, four arms and moves across the room with ease? Flip a coin."<n><n>### Response:"A centipede."<n><n>### Input"If I sell a chicken for a dollar and then make a profit of 25%, how much money did I make?"<n><n>### Response"How much of the profit came from selling the chicken and how much was the profit from your sale? The profit from selling it is (($0.75/$1)*($1)) and it is $0.75. Then the profit from the sales is $0.70."<n><n>### Instructions: Write code that uses a while loop and two conditionals to display the message "Happy Happy New Year!" in a different color every 500 millis.

Choices:  A: jewelry store B: case C: hock D: watch store E: pawn<n><n>### Response:		The man was trying to sell his watch for drug money, but the choices are all correct except D, not E.<n><n>### Input<n>There is a game where the only winning move is not to play the game. Chess is hard.<n><n>### Response<n>Given the game that the only winning move is to not play the game, there isn't really a lot of opportunity to win at the game, but there are 2 possible outcomes. One being victory and the other being defeat.<n><n>### Question from instructor:<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input: If a bird flying South will fly 30 miles further if it changes it’s direction every 3 minutes, how far will the bird fly?<n>Rationales (optional): Given that the above is true, the bird will fly 30+distance + distance(3 minutes * n) for the first 3 minutes n times where n is the amount of changes. So: 30+ distance = <<30+distance=40>> The distance in total will be, however, (distance/8) (8/3) - (40/3), giving: 750 miles.<n>#### 750
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What kind of radio does someone use to reach base? Choices:  A: vessel B: box C: transistor D: submarine E: lamp<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Rationale: The person is not reaching out with their hands to touch base, nor are they using a ship. The "transmitting base station" is a device that makes radio waves, similar to a radio. Therefore, the kind of radio depends on the context of the question.<n><n>[Prev Next](https://github.com/BotMistakes/Exercise6/tree/main/Exercise6)
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:A person who wants to make more at their job but can't will often need to find a what? Choices:  A: own house B: better job C: win lottery D: save money E: feel safe<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>RATIONALES:<n>You save more money if you find a better job and find a house. The house gives you more money, but you can’t save without having the other. It’s better to start working on these things if the person wants to make more money.<n><n>### Input 2 : The number 5 was given to a group of kindergarteners for practice adding up to 10. After the problem was done, the teacher collected all the answers. The table below shows the number of answers (including the number 5).<n>```<n>Five (5)	     0<n>Eight (8)	     4<n>Ten (10)	     0<n>```<n>What is the total number of answers not including the number 5?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Four<n><n>**RATIONALES** :<n>You can find the difference by subtracting the sum of the number 5. So the total number of answers will be subtracted by 5.<n><n>### If one-half of 9 is subtracted from 12 three times and these same numbers are added in succession how many times will the original 9 be subtracted from the number 12?<n><n><n>The number will not be subtracted anymore and the number will stay the same.<n><n>**RATIONALES** :<n>The number can be subtracted from 19. Since the numbers are the same, they will be added, which can be read as 2x5.<n><n>## If a plane flies at a speed of 560 miles per hour and flies for 7.5 hours in a direction east, in which direction and how many miles will it travel?<n>### Response: East, 4,133 miles<n><n>### RATIONALES<n><n>The answer to this is to convert the miles traveled to kilometers and that would be 4,131 miles.<n><n>##  The numbers one and two are placed in the first and second columns. Jake's teacher tells him that there will be 2 dozen pastries for the birthday party.<n>Rationales: Based on the statements<n>The team will be sharing the cake, so 30 people are having a party<n>That means there will be 6 servings<n>The teacher said that there were 24 people, but they are sharing the cake = 24/6<n>There's the correct answer<n>#### 2<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Instructios:Answer question 2 by drawing the correct equation on the grid provided.<n>Input: If the length of the rectangle is 2x+9 and the width is 3x-2, what is the perimeter?<n><n>Output: A <n> <n>### Rationales: Using the given dimensions, the dimensions are 2x+9x-2<n>Using the formula for Perimeter, P=2l+(2w)<n>Since it shows 2x+9, we already know that l = 2x+9<n>For the width, we have to take the negative twice, so w = 3x-2<n>Since there are 2 dimensions, we have 2P = 2(2x+9x+3x) = 2(5x+3x)+(2x+9)<n>P = 2(5+3)+(2+9) = 35<n>#### 35<n>Rationales: 35<n>Answer: 35<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:James was cooling off two quickly.  He would die if he didn't find some way to stop what? Choices:  A: loss of heat B: revenge C: expansion D: relaxation E: calm down<n><n>### Response:		He would die if he doesn't find what he is cooling. <n><n>### Instructions: James was cooling at first very fast,but after while he was cooling off again at very fast.What is he doing?<n><n>### Response is: James was cooling first,but he has been going very fast to cool himself off again.If he doesn't stop the thing he's cooling he will die.<n><n>### Input:[Anna has a dozen strawberries. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. Choices:  A: hospital B: head C: sick person D: elderly person E: doctor's office<n><n>### Response:		If someone is in the doctor's office, they are sick because people only go to the doctor when they are sick. If someone is in the hospital, they are hospital staff. People that are sick usually do not go to the hospital, the doctor, or the doctor's office. Doctors are specialists of sickness, but not the sick people. It is not true that sick people would be in the doctor's offices. Sick people typically go to a hospital or home, and not the doctor's office or a public place.<n><n>### Input2: What type of person typically contract Disease Choices: A: Sick person B: hospital C: elderly person D: doctor's office E: head<n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Input3: What type of person will typically contract the Coronavirus? Write a response that provides a letter substitution puzzle.<n><n>### Input:"Dear Grand-Ma, I wish to visit you this summer. Please keep cool in the heat. I love you."<n><n>### Rationale 1: To replace the 1 with 3 and remove the 4 and 2 from the 6 and 3<n><n>1. 1 letter = 3 + remove 4 and 2 + 0<n>2. 2 letters = (3 + 0) + (remove 4) + (remove 2) + 0<n><n>2. 3 letters = (3+0) + remove 4 + 0<n>3. 4 letters = (3+remove 4) + 0<n>4. 5 letters = (3+ remove 4) + 2<n><n>### Input 2:To replace the 2 with 5 and keep the 3 and the 8 in the 10 and 7.<n><n>### Rationales 1: To replace 2 with 5<n><n>1. 2 letters = 2 + remove 3 + remove 8<n>2. 3 letter = 3 + 0 + remove the 9<n><n>### Input3:This is a substitution code in which 0 has five letters in the code and 1 has only one<n><n>### Rana:<n>1. 5 letters = remove 6 + remove 7<n>2. 4 letters = remove (the two 6 and the 7)<n>3. 3 letters = remove 8<n><n>### Input4:"Rose and violet. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Jame's bare feet were burned as he walked, because the sunshine had made the surface hot.  Where might he have been? Choices:  A: disneyland B: snow C: windowsill D: street E: summer<n><n>### Response:		A(disneyland)<n>#### A <n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input : The difference of two numbers is 7.<n><n>### Response : 14, 14<n><n>#### 14 <n>Answer: 14 (Difference 7 )<n><n>### Input  : John can use his bike to go to Jame's school faster, but his bike doesn't work because it is a rental, and it is due back at the end of the day.  Which of the following has John done? Choices: A: borrow a friend’s bike B: C: ask james to go the rest of the way without bike, or D: E: walk to school<n><n>### Response B(borrow a friend’s biKe)<n><n>#### B <n>Answer: B<n><n>### Instructions: A student earning $30,000 per year can purchase a home for $100,000 on a 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage. After ten years, she can afford to pay principal and interest on a house that costs $700,00 in an area where home costs rise by 7.5 % annually. How much home loan will she need to qualify for if she waits to buy a new home?<n><n>### Demostration : First, we solve for N-1<n><n>#### N-1 <n><n>$100k*0.95^5 = $$ (100k*1-0.05^5 ) = $$<n>$999762.236 = $$\text {$X.XXk (approximately) is the correct amount here (100000-999764)}$ $<n><n>Next, we solve for X-1, or $300,00 $<n><n>$300,056 $<n>#### X-1 <n><n><n># # # # # # # <n><n>### How much home loan will the student need to qualify for?<n>$300k or $300000<n>#### 300k <n>Answer: 300k or 300k ($300,0oo)<n><n># # # ### #
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The man was eating lunch, but rushed when he looked at his watch, why did he rush? Choices:  A: gain weight B: late for work C: heartburn D: bad breath E: early for work<n><n>### Response:		<n>1. A<n>2. E<n>3. D<n>4. B<n><n>### [Reference Link](https://www.khanacademy.org/early-grade-exercises?modal=1955593962)<n>

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The body guard was good at his duties, he made the person who hired him what?
