Why can't we know about a room without telling whether it's A,B,C, or D?  What is this even supposed to mean?<n><n>#### A1.0<n>Answer: C(B): bowel<n><n>### Input<n>You’re asked how to complete the number sequence:<n><n>15, 17, 19,? 20, 23, 25, 31, 32, 36<n><n>The answer is 27, 29, 34. How?<n><n>### Solution<n>The answer is 34.  We're told that the sequence follows the pattern 2n+1.  The first four numbers are 15, 15+1 = 17, 35, 35+1 = 36 33<n><n>#### 34<n>Answer: 34<n><n>### Input(2): A shop owner knows that if she charges $5 more for an item, customers will buy two instead of just one item. When she applies this rule of higher prices sells more merchandise, sales increase.  Determine how much more she sells each day.<n><n>### Solution:<n>Let x represent the cost of the item to start with. Our rule is that for each 5 dollars increase, that will encourage purchasing two items.  Each 5 dollars increase in the price will encourage two additional items sold.<n>1. The cost of items sold in a day in the beginning is x. We will write 5x to represent the cost of the first added 5 dollars.  2. The cost of items now is 6x + 5x = 11x.   We will write 7x + 5x to represent 12 more than 6x.  Each 5 dollar increase encourages purchase of 2 items, and we need all the encouragement twice, because of the rule, so if 7x + 12 is 170 or more, then the amount must increase by 130, which will be 260.

Choices:  A: sun B: sky C: candle D: house E: lamp<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### <n><n>#### B<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Complete the following table of values. <n>In your first column, place the number of years you think each event will happen in the future from today. <n>Your remaining columns display the value of your chosen currency. <n>Your first currency is worth $100.<n><n><n>### Instraction:<n>If the population of Alpha 3 doubles every 5 years and beta doubles every 10 years, at what rate would the population of Alpha and Beta grow together when the ratio of their populations is 2:3?<n><n>### Solution:<n>Rate of Alpha’s population doubles every <n>5 years: $<<100(2)>$ <<200>> $<<50%>> $<<100>> = 2:3 and it takes <n><n>Rate of Beta’s population doubles every: $<<10(3)>> $<<$30$>><n><n>####  %<n><n>We have a growth rate of: $ \text{Growth Rate in YEARS = }(5\text{n})/2 - (10\text{n}) / 3 $<n><n>where $ \text{n} $ is $ \text{Years to Growth Rate} $<n><n>Our growth rate in years: $ 2\text{n} - 3\text{n} \text{ years } = 0$<n><n>$ \text{Grow} / \text{ith Rate}= 0 \text{ years in 2:3 ratio}\implies$<n><n>$ 0 \text{/ 2 = 0}\implies$<n><n>$\ $ No growth rate since 0/0 $<n><n>####  %\text{ }<n><n>### Instuctions: Answer the following multiple-choice questions.<n><n>### Inuctions: <n><n>### Instractions: <n><n><n>### Inputs: <n><n>## Instructions: <n><n>Input: Your mother asks you to find the perimeter of your school. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. What does my total cost to create my boat anchor using a 100-pound weight cost?<n><n>### Response (complete):<n><n>The total cost to create my **boat anchor** using a **100 pound weight** costs $23.4<n><n>The total cost includes the cost of the **$8 for welding**. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would you find performers on a platform in public? Choices:  A: arena B: building C: dock D: concert hall E: museum<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n>### Demonstraion:<n>Input: How many times can you flip a coin, toss a die, or draw a card and land on the same result? For the first question, the flipped coin landed on heads. For the second question, the die had a 6 on it.<n>The three questions will show an example of how the answer would be 1 for flipping a coin and drawing 3 for drawing cards from a regular deck of playing cards.<n><n>The three cases for rolling three dice will be, the first three dice rolls from a six dice.<n><n>When flipping a coin it will either be heads or tails. <n><n>For rolling three dice, on the first flip four dice will be rolled but only three are kept. The first three dice rolls in a game of craps.<n><n>In drawling a card, there will only be 52 different possibilities not 44.<n><n>There could be an infinite number of ways to land on the same result, even if you had cards like this you would draw 3 different cards in one turn with this, 1 card = <<one card=1>>1. 10 cards = <<10 cards=10>>10<n><n>The answer will be 1 because, you can only land on the same result by flipping and drawing out 32 / 3 = <<32/3=11>>11 or 32 cards.<n><n>#### 1<n>Answer: 2<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer: 3<n><n>#### 3<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Instuction:Answer the following multiple -choice question. Write a response that describes a task.<n><n>### Request: I want to find the most common name in a collection of different names.<n><n>### Solution: This solution will use the array name-collection to store the data that each value will be stored in the variable name-collection. Each time a name is found, we will add it as a new name-collection. After all names have been entered, the code will print out the name that has been repeated the most as name-repeated.<n><n>```<n>char name[50]; //Variable name-collection creates a name-collection with a storage capacity of 50.

A building is 126 yards high. What is the volume of the building?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>The height of the building is equal to the square root of a cubed value<n>The volume of the building is equal (213)6.<n>The answer to the question above is that, 126 yard is equal to, 126 yards x ( 275 )3 = 3673<n>We can also write 126 yard / cubed to find the cubed value, so that we get that, 127 = (126 )3, then we square the value, and find that the square root of 1729 is equal to 3673.<n>### Input:<n>The answer lies in how you solve the equation with the least amount of complexity and how you can rationalize your answer the best. The answer is not going to be 40, 16, 4, 16. To come up with the answer, we must find what the square root of 40 is, since its asked which is the least amount of complex.<n>The sum is:<n>40² + 16² + 4² + 16², which equals 40. Its not 40 when we remove 16² and 4² to simplify the problem.<n>The sum is<n>40² + (64 - 16²) = 40² (40)<n>Now, we must find the sum of the square of (64 - 4²)<n>Then we subtract to get:<n>40² (4) (40) = 402<n>402 = 1600 (40) <n>40² (600 / 40) = 150 + 120 + 6<n>Then the answer is 150 +120+6<n>### Input: You have a box that contains four lights 3 white

Choices:  A: restaurant B: congress C: envelope D: mail box E: cheese store<n><n>### Response:		<n>C - congress.<n>### Instruction The following question uses a lettered set of rules.<n>### Demonstation: Rule A will do the following:<n>Rule A:<n>####A. If a number is even and even = even<n>####B. Let a + b = c and  c < b<n>####C. If a and b are both even than a + b will be even.<n>####D. When adding a,b, c the even ones will even each time.<n>####E. If c is odd then its not even.<n><n>### Rule F:<n><n>####F. if a =b than a^2 will equal  b^2<n><n>A 200 200  A=100 even<n><n>B 100 100  B=50 even<n><n>C 121 116 32 even<n><n>D 116 19 even<n><n>E 23 even<n><n>####E. the odd numbers will have something missing.<n><n>A+B = A+B<n><n>A+C = A+C+18<n><n>A+D+A= A+(D+A)+2B<n><n>A+E = A+(A+3D)<n><n>F. a^2 = b^2<n><n>If A^2 = B^2 then A = B<n><n>If A = B then A=B<n>Q: Is A = B?<n><n>####H. the odd numbers will not have even numbers in them.<n><n>A+C+A =A+C<n><n>3B= B<n><n>####I. The parity rule says that if a = b then b is even.<n><n>Q: If A = B then B is even.<n><n>####J. B - E<n><n>200 - 33=167<n><n>100 - 99=1<n><n>50 +16 = 66<n><n>100 + 33 = 133<n><n>### Rule E:<n>The parity rule states that if two numbers are equal then one of them is even.<n><n>$A=B\rightarrow B= A$<n><n>The parity rule for addition states that if two numbers have the same even and odd components, then the sum will also be even.<n><n>$
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where can you eat fruit on a red bridge? Choices:  A: refrigerator B: engineering school C: san francisco D: tree E: market<n><n>### Response:		The answer is B: engineering school.<n>### Rationale: The answer is B, Engineering school, because the only food eating place that is on a bridge is a school.<n><n>### Input<n>### Choices:<n>A) _______________________________________________________________________<n><n>### B) ____________________________________________________
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What makes people happy when it is surprising and unexpected? Choices:  A: joke B: humor C: frightened D: fight E: laughter<n><n>### Response:		<n>The choices A and C. Frightened is one way to make people happy. Surprise and laughter is the other way to make people happy, so B.<n>#### 1<n>Answer: 1<n><n>### Input<n>The number of players in a game is 4 less than 3 times the number of players in a completely different game. The number of players in that completely different game is 22 less than twice the number of players in the first game. Can you find the number of players in each game?<n>[Rationales: For the First game the number of players is:<n>($4-3*x)/$2<n>Since $4-3*x = 7 and $2 = 2, we get: x = 7/2.<n>We plug: 7/2 into $4-3*7/2, we get: (x)($4-3*7)/2 = 11.<n>11/2 is a little over 5, therefore: There are 5 players in the first game.]<n><n>[Rationales for the 2nd game: Let x = twice the number of players x = 2x<n>Since 2x = 2(x) = 4x,<n>Then 2x = 4x = x*4<n>x = 4, there are 4 players in the game.<n><n>### In each of the following pairs of two-digit numbers, can you find a rule that will help you identify either a and b or b and a? How are the two-digit numbers related?<n>Rationales for 1st pair: For a and b are 14 and 29.<n>To find a b by finding 14 we subtract from 39 by 14 = 25<n>To find b for a we subtract 25 from 39 by b = 14<n>For the other cases we subtract by the number of 2 the second one is (48-c48c/2 (and the other one (26-c (or (c-26) (but 26 is always less then the 48 since the 26 is the only way it can get there.<n><n>### Input : Favorite vegetable among the three friends is corn. Their are 53 days remaining until the end of February. How

How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The man took 3 hours every morning for grooming, what is the likely result with his job? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Dancing for a long time will lead you to become what? What is ten times 5  =<<10*5=50>>50<n>2. What is 20 times 5 =<<20*5=100>>100<n>3. What is 30 times 5 = <<30*5=150>><n>4. Subtract 30 from 50, you get 20. Choices:  A: wrong B: death of C: bad D: negative E: evil<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A:<n><n>Input:A group of six friends planned the costs to share a car, they planned to have a car wash, because there was money collected, they planned to cover the total cost of the car, so at the end how much money will everyone have to cover?<n><n>#### A:  It's $1,700 minus $500 = $1,200<n><n>There are 6 people in total<n><n>Therefore each person have to pay $1,20 for the rest of the cost<n><n>#### B:<n><n>After finding out the result of the trial, the judge tells the murderer…<n><n>#### B:  He is evil.<n><n>There are four options which are wrong, death of, bad, negative, evil<n><n>Evil can not be a possibility because in some cases people would think he is evil but in this particular case he is a murderer and murder isn’t bad in any way<n><n>The judge tells the murder…<n>If there was no wrong then he is evil<n><n>#### C:<n><n>After finding the result of the trial the judge tells the murder<n>C) Bad<n><n>In some ways you can say this person has done something really bad<n><n>For example, if you kill someone you are bad<n><n>In the case of the judge, he said he is bad that is a possibility<n><n>A murderer is an evil person, but you can say they are good to get them out of jail<n><n>In the above question a was the answer but in the below case C is right.<n><n>#### D: <n><n>After the judge tells the murder the murderer is not bad<n><n>The judge tells him he is…<n><n>#### D: Death of.<n><n>The judge says<n><n>But before you can say he is death of<n><n>There must be something he did to prove he is death of the murderer<n><n>The murder must have killed someone, because if someone doesn’t die you are not death of that person<n><n>He could have been…<n><n>Therefore he must have killed someone<n><n>#### E:<n><n>Evil can’t be possible because in some cultures they may say he is evil<n><n>### Answer here<n><n>#### 1200<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: A group was traveling through a tunnel when
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The billionaire donated a large sum to his former college, this allowed them to construct a new science what? Choices:  A: fraternity house B: bank C: big town D: big city E: building<n><n>### Response:		<n>E(building)<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input:The billionaire donate 2.5 bil$ to college<n><n>Output 420<n><n>### Solution:<n>If we use the 23rd percentile, we find that it results in an amount of money that the billionaire donated.<n><n>Let x = amount of money that the bank donated<n><n>x % 23 = 0<n><n>x = 0% * 23<n><n>x = 500/100<n><n>x = $500<n><n>If we plug 25000 million $ into the equation<n><n>(25000 $ * 500/ 100 = 3.1 billion $<n><n>$3.1 billion $ * 1 = $3.1 billion $

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Many containers full of goods are unloaded where after their long sea journey Choices:  A: port B: cargo ship C: refrigerator D: food E: lorry<n><n>### Response:		D<n>### Rationales:<n><n>The goods unloaded are lorry/trucks since it is after their long sea journey, it must be in the form of load.<n><n><n>####  D<n>Answer:  D<n><n>### Input : When she was walking in the woods, Alicia heard a strange noise. This means a dog snaring it sound.<n><n><n>#### D<n>Answer : D<n><n>## Challenge:<n>You will work to solve a problem of the sort as described in the below scenario. Write a response that includes the complete solution you have devised.<n><n>Below is a procedure that describes what we need to do. Write a response that describes a method to complete the request.<n><n>#### Instruction :<n><n>```python<n>def multiply_and_sum(nums, val, n):<n>    # write your code here<n>    sum_list = []<n>    for num in nums:<n>        num_pow = int(num**val)<n>        sum_list.append(sum_list.append(num_pow) + num_pow % n)<n><n>    return sum_list[-1]<n>```<n><n><n>#### Instruction:<n>Below is a method that we need to complete. Write a response that correctly returns a string based on the input string.<n><n>```python<n><n># Write your code here<n>```<n><n>### Challenge :<n>Write a response that demonstrates the correct answer.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:An attempt to confirm an applicant's reference would fail if the reference does what? The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. Choices:  A: beast B: ugly C: ugliness D: satellite E: top of mountain<n><n>### Response:		A: beast<n><n>### Rationale:<n>She loved a beast because <n><n>`1/a = <<1/a=1>>1`, is the simplified version. <n><n>### A: One<n><n>#### Beast<n><n><n><n>### Input<n><n>### What is 0.191 x 0.143?<n><n>### Answer: 0.0014235724<n><n>### Input <n><n>### What's the value of x + 2(x – 2) – 4(x + 3) + x?<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>We need to use the distribution property a lot <n><n>1. x + 2(3 - x) + 4(5 - 3)<n>  1. x + (6 - x)<n>  2. (2 - x)<n>2. (2 -2) + (5 - 3) * 4<n>  1. -4 -2<n>  2. 4(7)<n>3. (4 - x) + (7 - 4)(1 - x)<n>  1. -8 + 1<n>  2. 1(1)*(1)<n>### Answer: -7<n><n><n>### Raising to a power<n><n>The product of any two numbers times another power of the same number is ______.<n><n>### Answer in steps:<n><n># 1<n><n>### Example:2 x 2x 2 <n><n>### Raison: The result becomes 2^(2+2) = 8<n><n># 2<n><n>### Example: 2^4 <n><n>### Reason 4 x 2 = 8<n><n>### Riesen: 8 x 2 = 16<n><n># 3<n><n>### Example 2^(4/2)<n><n>### Ration: 2^2 = 4 = 2^1 = 2<n><n># 4<n><n>### Example in steps: <n><n>### Example1<n><n>### Rasion<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where is a telephone booth likely to be red? Choices:  A: airport B: gotham city C: london D: city E: gas stations<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>Answer:<n>A<n>```<n>### Explanation:<n>### Input:How many hours are there between noon on March 14th at midnight on March 15th?<n>### Demonstartion:<n>If noon starts at 12:00, and midnight is 23:59, then there are 15 hours from noon to midnight.<n><n>### Response - Answer:<n><n>### Explanantion:<n>### Answer:<n>15<n><n>### Exlanation<n>Since the time between noon and midnight is a little more than 12 hrs.<n><n>12 hrs is the 1st part and the next 3 hrs is the 2nd part.<n>If you were to do this in a clock, just say that from 12:01 it's 12:33 and then from 13:01 it'd be 15:01.<n><n>### Input where you do not need to ask two people about a certain thing: Do these four people approve of the president?<n>Choices A: Yes B: No C: They don't know D: They'd rather watch you do a cross-check.<n><n>### Exposition:<n><n>### Answer: B<n><n>### Explantion: They are approving a president's decisions. If they approve or disapprove, they are doing so for the same or different president.<n><n>Choices where they approve but disapprove the same president: A<n><n>Choices where their approval is the same and disapproval is the same but different for the president: C<n><n>Choices where both are approving: B<n><n>## Demo 4: This time, you asked two friends of yours. Both friends had the same answer. Do these four people approval of the president?<n><n>Choices: A) Yes B) No C) They don't know,D) They'd rather watch.<n><n>Answer:<n><n>## Exposition:<n>## Answer: B<n>

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would you stand in a line and need a coat if it is cold? Choices:  A: graph B: bank at noon C: good book D: post office E: bus stop<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>#print myresponse<n>print ("14") <n>```<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## # Demonstration: <n>#### 14(answer)<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input : <n>This is a question about reading. Pick the letter on the right if you think it is better than the letter on the left.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>```python<n>for letter in choice[0-3]:<n>	if letter == "a":<n>		print ("a")<n>	print "b"<n>	#If the first answer is "a" - print "a"<n>	elif letter == "b":<n>		print letter<n>	print "c"<n>	#If second letter is not "a" - print the letter<n>	elif letter ==  "c":<n>		print "c"	<n>```<n><n>## # Rationales<n><n>### 14<n>A is better than B because B and C are lower case letters. It takes a greater number of letters to be considered a word.<n><n>### 20<n>B is better than A because A and C are lower case. It takes a greater amount of letters to be considered word.<n><n>## # Rationale<n><n>### 30 is better<n>B is better than C because it's bigger when graphed.<n><n>### A is better<n>Graph at 2pm<n><n>### Better<n>Because it's not busy<n><n>### Good book<n>Books are at the library with their book shelves<n><n>### Better than no coat<n>Inside the bank is warm<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:where do you typically find a trash can in the city? Choices:  A: park B: motel C: corner D: bus stop E: store front<n><n>### Response:		The trashcans are found mostly in corner, bus stop, motel and in stores. But in some city trash can is in park.<n><n>#### C, D<n>Answer: C and D <n><n>## | :page_facing_up: Question 1:<n><n>Write a function that uses a parameter (n), n for example, to generate a single element from an array A or an object A, but the element will be selected from n members of the array.<n><n>You don't have to actually implement the code because I expect you to explain it in words.<n><n>Use the example below to better demonstrate.<n><n>Input: An array containing the numbers 1 through 10.<n>Rationales: I assume you to do the explanation for this first question<n><n>Output:<n>14<n>#### Answer:<n>I am not sure what you expect but I guess it should show the index 6?<n><n>## | :books: Question 2:<n><n>Write a code that prints out an array element given the element's index.  <n>For example, if an Array contains the elements ['Jon', 'Ron', 'Marvin'] and index 3, and the input parameter is 3, then the program should print Jon is on the 3rd position in this array.<n><n>Also, the same code should work for the same input parameter but with a different array containing the elements ['Jon','Ron','Marvin', 'Ray', 'Mary'] and index 3 (where you expect that the program should print Jon, Marvin, Mary, Ray are on the 3rd positions in this array). You don't have to implement the code as I expect you to explain how it works.  <n>Here I will work with the last argument.<n><n>Input: ['Marion','Ron','Marine']<n>Rationales:<n>You don;t have to do explanations in this questions.<n><n>#### Answer:<n>In this code, n is the index of the element and element is the element of the nth index in your case the 3 element in the first array.<n><n>### Question 3:<n><n>Write a program that will print the first name of a person who has the last name of Doe. Assume the user passes the first and last names as a single string. The code should print something to the effect of "Doug".<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:John loves animals and he hates animal abuse.  Because of this, john is very careful about the places he goes.  Where might he avoid going? Choices:  A: pet store B: parking lot C: woodland D: north america E: park<n><n>### Response:		C<n>#### C<n><n>### Input<n>Tom's mom was going to cook his favorite food for dinner. Dinner is going to consist of a hot dog, a baked potato, and some steamed broccoli. But in the end, she forgot to buy a hot dog, forgot a knife for cutting the potato, and forgot the broccoli. How many total different foods could Tom have for dinner?<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### 2<n><n>### Instructions & Response<n>### Input: Mary and John were in the same second-grade class when they were students. The teacher decided to get the class acquainted. She called one person's name and asked each student to introduce himself or herself. Then, she asked the students to stand with the person to whom they had been introduced. The only rule was that a boy and girl could not be introduced to each other. Which rules did the teacher follow?<n><n>### A. All students in the same room<n><n>### B. The girls and boys sat at different sides of the room<n><n>### C. The person who introduced himself or herself stayed with the person they were introduced to<n><n>### Answer: C<n><n>#### C<n><n>***<n> <n> <n>### Input: The table has six columns with the number 21 in the first column and 23 in the third. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What would you tell ali to do if he bumps into you when you are walking? Choices:  A: work hard B: slow down C: wear shoes D: sell products E: speed up<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is A: work hard.<n><n>### Questions:<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>1. Answer the following problem. 2. Write your answer in complete sentences and show work where possible.<n><n>### Input <n>A carpenters needs to cut down 30 feet of 2x6 Pine wood. There’s been an error. He is supposed to cut down 3 foot of 2x6 pine wood. He bought one entire piece of lumber called a ‘board-foot’, How many board feet is contained in the single board-foot cut?<n><n>### Response<n><n>The Board foot contains 100 cubic inch units, with 12”x12”x1”. So 1 foot equals 12x12x1, and 1 cubic inch equals.0625x.0625x13.5, so 100 cu in = 625 x 625 x.0625 = 37.8<n><n>Answer: 37.8

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where is a good place to sore a wind instrument in you home? E: music store is also a good one because that is where you find the wind instrument.<n><n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would you find a binder containing homework assignments? Choices:  A: backpack B: bookcase C: office supply store D: office E: class room<n><n>### Response:		 The answer is the office supply store. Homework will be collected in the classroom, so the homework might be in the classroom. Homework will most likely be in the students' binder, however, the binder will most likely be in their backpack. If a student misplaces their binder, they would ask a classmate, and in the case that none are able to lend theirs, their parents would take them to an office supply store to get a new binder. The teacher most likely has extra paper in their office supply store that is for homework assignments and can be used by students in the classroom if students need excessive paper.<n>Homework will most likely be collected in the class room if the school offers free wifi or internet. The teacher may create or purchase their own materials and supply them to the students in the class room. The school may have free wifi, so that the students can also work in the library and not confine themselves to the house.<n><n>### Input : Find the value of 500 + 2500 + 3500<n><n>### Response : 6000 (500+2500+3500)<n><n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: It costs more for 64 pieces of fruit to have in a fruit basket that for 32 pieces of fruit. If each piece of fruit costs $1.69, how much more will it cost to have 64 pieces of fresh fruit than to have 32 pieces of fresh fruit?<n>Rationales : Each fruit costs 1.96, (1.69 +.25)<n>The costs for the fruit in the fruit basket is $<<1.69+.25=1.96>>1.96<n>The cost in the basket is $<<12+$1.96=$14.96>>14.96<n><n>The two answers I think are that either the basket has 54 or 24 pieces of fruit, for 32 pieces it costs less because it doesn't require 54 pieces of fruit<n><n>**I used more than one equation for this question because 1.69 + (1.69/64) is a lot easier to

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:If you see blinking lights in the air at night, what are you usually looking at? Choices:  A: carnival B: plane C: concert D: turned at night E: a penguin's bum<n><n>### Response:		C<n>#### C.Concert<n><n>### Input:$25<n>### Rationales:$20<n>#### 20<n>Answer: 25<n><n>### Input:"$20 / $5 =.4" and "4 / $20 =.05"<n>### Your task is to simplify the fractions.<n>### Rational:The first fraction is equivalent to the second one. In the second fraction, you just divide both the numerator and denominator by 4. <n>4/5 is equal to 4 x 5/5 = 20<n>.4 is equal to 1/25<n>####.2<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Your job is to write a function that takes x, the length in meters of a 1/2-meter square roadway, and returns the length of the roadway in feet.<n># x is in 0.5 meters.<n><n>### Inputx<n><n>### Outputx<n><n>#function{<n>#   x/3<n>#}<n><n>#y is the function<n>### Input7<n>### Output28.5<n>#y( 7)<n>#### 28.5<n>y is working.<n><n>### Your problem in English is:<n>> "I have three candles in the shape of a star. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Sarah thought that she had been home all evening.  That meant that the only time to leave was when? Choices:  A: early morning B: day time C: night D: afternoon E: daytime<n><n>### Response:		<n>A:Early morning<n><n>### Rational:<n>The answer is A because early morning is the first time that Sarah could leave her house. This is correct because we know Sarah thought she had been home all day because if she did not think she had been home all night then she would not be able to leave in the morning because if she did she would leave earlier than expected.<n><n>### Input<n>Write the correct response that completes the sentence. Select all answers that may be correct.<n>A: After the final test scores are calculated for the class.<n>B: After the final test is taken for the grade.<n>C: When the class receives all their final scores for the class.<n>D: After the final test has been graded by their teacher.<n><n>### Response<n>Correct answer is after the scores are calculated for the test because the test scores will determine the final grades for classes.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>All answers contain calculations or final results that will be determined after the teacher has finalized everything about the class.<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>1) The answer is the next in a complete serial progression of the answers.<n>2) The next number follows the sequence with one constant of 3<n>3) The next number is 1/3rd (1/3) of the number before it.<n><n>### Problem Set:<n>A: 1<n>B: 2<n>C: 3<n>D: 4<n>E: 1/2<n>F: 1.5<n>G: 2.5<n><n>### Raven:<n>A is only 0.5, that is not the value of 1.<n>B is not 1 so it is false<n>C is not 2.5 so it is false<n>D is 1 and is true<n>E is 2 and is false<n>F is 1.5 so it is true<n>G is 2.5 and is true<n><n>### Instant Question:<n>Pablo’s mother agrees with him paying 1.5 cents per page for everything he chooses to read. He plans to save that money for some candy, so he typically reads books that are exactly 200 pages. What was his total bill after the car wash was cancelled?<n><n>### Answer:<n>50 cents

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:There weren't enough chairs for everyone. Choices:  A: article B: adjective C: interjection D: conjunction E: pronoun<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Rationales for the answers <n>A:Articles:The, a, or an. <n>B:Adjectives:describing words of a person or place.<n>C:Interjections:short phrases of expression.<n>D:conjunctions:joining words with the conjunction 'and'.<n>E:pronouns:words that substitute nouns.<n><n>### Pronouns:Pronouns are words that substitute nouns and should agree in number with the nouns they replace.<n>#### I<n>Demonstration: I'm going.<n>####2<n>Rationales: I's are pronouns as verbs and pronouns are words that replace nouns as subjects. Since the verb is in the first person and the noun is in the second person, they should both be I.<n>####3<n>Rationales: That's good.<n>####4<n>Rationales: She said that.<n><n># Section 2<n><n>### Demystifying the difference between 'that' and 'which' in a 'which of' sentence.<n><n>### Inputs: Which of these two things do you like better, a bike or a skateboard?<n>Demonstration for A: Biking down that hill was fun until it turned into a roller coaster.<n>Rationales for A:That refers to something non-essential, such as bike.<n>#### B<n>Demonstration For B: It was the coolest bike that I've ever had.<n>Rationales For B:Which refers to something essential, such as a roller coaster in Biking down...<n><n>### Which of the following prepositions is incorrect? <n>####1<n>Input: Which of these sentences is correct? A book on poetry costs ten dollars. In the bookstore, the currency is pounds. If one pound is equivalent to ten dollars, how much should the poetry book cost for two pounds?<n><n>### Response:"B", the correct answer is £40 pounds (£40/10 = 4, 00/1 = 0 and 4, 0 + 4, 0 = 8, 0, 0).<n><n>### Why: The two pounds in the math book is equivalent one pound for every $2, so the poem book costs two dollars for every pound.<n><n>---<n><n>### Input:-8 divided by 4 = 2<n>><n>---<n><n>## #Demonstration:In the equation below,  ___  represents the ________. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where should you find a school in? Choices:  A: residential neighborhood B: mosque C: every city D: prague E: community<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input<n>The difference in ages between Richard & Hurley is 24 years. If at age 16 Hurley is 2 years older than Richard, and at age 70 Richard is twice as old as Hurley, how old is Richard now?<n><n>### Demostration<n>Richard should be 54 years old right now. He will double his age till he is twice as old as hurley.<n>```<n>Richard - 24(years younger Hurley) = 2 + Hurley(years older) + Richard - 2<n>Richard(3 years younger than Hurley) + Hurley(3 years older than Richard) = 1(Richard and Hurley are the same age now)<n>3(Richard older than Hurley) + 3(Hurley younger than Richard) = 0(Richard and Hurleys are the same age)<n>Richard should be(3 years younger than hurley) = 3(Hurleys age - Richards age - 2)<n>Richard is(21 years old) or Richard should be 54<n>```<n><n>### Input and Analysis<n>```<n>After reading his books, he bought $16 worth of candy and he had 3 left over(least favored case).<n>It means he took out $13 from the cost of the candy so the cost of 5 books is = $ 13*5 = 65.<n>```<n>### Demostractrion<n>```<n>The remainder = 1000-560 = 440<n>6 - 8 = -2 => so each has to pay 200<n>```<n>1.63 * 100 = 529<n>```<n>529 - 88.12 = 440 - 88.6 - 88.7 = 372.5<n>```<n>372.5/6= 62.1<n>$20 + $40 = 62
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where is a notebook often purchased? The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. Choices:  A: feeble B: bullbleep C: cow D: female E: charging prey<n><n>### Response:		<n>> E<n>#### 💪💪𣿫𣿫<n><n>### Instructions:<n>This question does not require the use of a calculator.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:James drove his niece to her father. Choices:  A: houses B: bedroom C: istanbul D: open tress E: gym<n><n>### Response:		 A<n><n>### Input The price-earnings ratio for the company was 18. If the company paid a dividend of $3.20 last year, how much did the company earn?<n><n>### Prerence: 2019 / ((18/18)^(((3.20/18)*2)))*18*10 = 2019/((18/18)/((3.20/0)) = 2011<n><n>### Response:(9.2*18)*10 = 170<n><n>### Instrucion: The price-book ratio is the value of all the company's stock shares expressed as a percentage of the company's book value. In other words, it is the value of a company's stock divided by the price of its assets. For example, if a firm has a total market value of $90 million, with assets valued at $60 million, its P/B ratio would be (90/60) = 1.5. For companies, a number below 1 indicates that they are selling for less than their book value. A number above 1 means they are selling for more than their book value.<n><n>### Rationale: Market -> Market Value which is the total number of shares times the share price.<n>Book Value means total assets - total liabilities<n><n>### Input = 240 / 15 = 16<n><n>### Answer - 16<n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:People celebrate by going places and riding rides.  What's one obvious place people might go to celebrate? Choices:  A: state park B: opera C: disneyland D: carnival E: park<n><n>### Response:		C)  Because people go to Disneyland with their friends and family and they will always get happy<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>###<n><n>###<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Stopping being married to one another was a costly task, the lawyers and their what were astronomical? The choices are A. free time, B. time, C. divorce fees, D. legal fees, E. being lonely. The choice that was the costly thing to them was the legal fees, because if you want to get divorced it is not free. It costs quite a bit of money and time.<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Choose all answer from the choices given.<n>A. 15 -21<n>B. 7 - 6<n>C. 28<n>D. I could ask you how that process will feel.<n><n>#### 2nd Demonstimation: The answer will not make sense in this context because “God” will not exist<n><n>The grief I was referring to was when you are being suicided, you end up having a misery, a misery of being born.<n><n>### Input for second response:What will happen if I do have children<n><n><n>### Response<n><n>You will have lots of joy. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. That's because, the school system and the community need to be funded from 1 single source. If the school system and community was to come up with the funding, then the community would be split into districts, which could hurt people.<n><n>### Input The next time that Ms. Marisa gives a quiz, she plans to choose three students from a pool of twelve classmates to represent their class<n><n>### Response A: Sam, Sarah and Sara<n><n>### Instuction:Explain your response using the following:<n>What other students would not be chosen from that particular time?<n>Why would you select those three students for that activity?<n><n>---<n>**Comment:** Sara, Sam and Sarah is a 4 letter word but only 3 slots available for Ms. Marisa's Quiz. We can solve this by adding another letter, to get it to 4/3 = 1.<n><n>Now Sam, Sarah and Sala will be getting that quiz.<n><n>---<n> **Comment 2:** So Ms. Marisa is choosing 3 students, and Sarah and Sam will be chosen out of the 10 remaining students. <n><n># Mixed Grade<n><n>### Response 2:Suzie, Sonia and Steve<n><n>### Instutcion:<n>Explain your response using these questions: What other students would not

A movie ticket was 13 times more expensive than a video game.<n><n>#### Concepts:<n><n>* Use place value to distinguish between different numbers, such as 25,26,27 and 28.<n>    * Example. $1.25 = <<1.25>>1 and $.29 = << $.29>>$.29 (29 cents).<n>* Understand that there are different types of variables: constants and variables.<n>    * Example: _ 8 = _8<n><n>#### Instruction: The price of each ticket was $7.25.<n><n>Rationales: The first 20 tickets are sold at 15% discount and $7.25 x 0.15 = <<7.25 x.15=1.1>>1.1<n>So the 20 tickets cost $7.25 - 1.1 = <<7.20-1.1=5.35>>5.35<n>And the rest of the tickets cost $72.50 - 5.35 = <<72.5-5.35=67.15>>67.15<n>#### 67.15 and 11.85<n>Answer: 67.1461853125, 11.849609375<n><n>#### Instruction.
