Choices:  A: overhead compartment B: chair C: hospital D: in shirt E: business meeting<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A<n>Rationales: The most appropriate answer, the attache case is a very important small bag and so it would very likely be carried with you.<n><n>#### B<n>Rationales:<n>#### C<n>Rationales: Hospital? I would hope not.<n>#### D<n>Rationales: To a business meeting? Sure!<n>#### E<n>Rationales: I'm not sure this is important, it's just a guess.<n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Instructions:The following are the scores of a math test. 6 2 1 3 10 6 6 4 3 6. 1. Which score is greatest? 2. How many more points were there between the scores of 2 and 1? 3. What is the least possible sum? 4. What is the least common multiple of 2 and 6? 5. Find the sum of the digits of each of the scores and divide by 3.<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>#### 7<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Instuctions:1. Select the option that completes this incomplete statement. 49 cents ____ the price of the book if you have your student ID with you. 2. Identify whether the statement is true or false. If false, select a suitable correction. A) The amount needed to purchase the book depends on whether or not you have your student ID. B) Including your student ID is not needed to get the discount. C) You are only allowed to use your student ID card once per semester. D) The cost of your ID card is not added to the amount you need to purchase the book. <n><n>#### A<n>Rationale: C) true, false false.<n>#### B<n>Rationale: D) C) true, false.<n>#### C<n>Rationale: A) true, false false<n>#### D<n>Rationale: false false<n>#### D)<n>Answer: C) 2 <n><n>### Instution: 1. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What country has with the capital of Amsterdam has a Fortis bank? Choices:  A: netherlands B: utrecht C: brussels D: belgium E: denmark<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer is ____.<n><n>### Instructions:<n>The answer you should provide is part of the following table.<n><n>|Country: | Capital: |  Bank:  |  Answer       |<n>|---------|-----------|----------|-------------|<n>| Nether- | Amsterdam | Forntis | C : bel- |<n>| lands |   | | gium | | |<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Diving off a cliff for a cartoon character often ends in comedic what? Choices:  A: exhilaration B: dismemberment C: spinal injuries D: getting wet E: splats<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following question that tests your ability to select an answer by considering more than one option.<n>### Demonstation:<n><n>What are 2 real places that start with the letter O?<n>A. Australia and Omaha<n>B. Omaha and Australia<n>C. Antarctica and Omaha<n>D. Antarctica and Australia<n>Answers: A<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:James is apply for a job that he really wants. He knows that it will be a good fit and he has experience, but he doesn't have all the qualifications that they're asking for, so he's worried about what? Choices:  A: acceptance B: rejection C: hope D: less sleep E: employment<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Why: Because he wants the job, that's why he is worried about less sleep. He's not worried about acceptance, rejection or hope.<n><n>#### Question 2<n><n>### Input:-1 x 3 / 2 = - <<-1 x 3/2=-3>> -3 / _____ = _____<n><n>### Response:-1 x 3/ 2= - << <-1 x 3/->=-3>> / 2- =-3 / -1= - <<-3-=-1>> -1<n><n>### Why:-1 x 3 = -<< <-1 x 3 = <-3>> -3 / 2= -3 / -1=1<n><n>### Summary<n><n>Input: A sum of three consecutive negative numbers is 72. What is the least of the three?<n>Rationales:-1 + <<-2-=-3>>-3 / 2= 3 / -1  which would be -<1> / - 1=<n><n>### Answer:-1<n>

Choices:  A: mail orders B: demand satisfaction C: place money on counter D: pay merchants with money E: spend money<n><n>### Response:		Place Money on Counter, Demand Satisfaction, Pay merchants with money, Spend Money<n><n>### Input-1A: When a woman and five men work in the field together, it takes them to work five days to finish what exactly? Choices: A: planting a field B: tilling a field C: digging a hole D: plowing a field E: fixing a gate<n><n>### Rationales: The women and the men work together to farm a field for five days. So, it takes them five days to finish tilling a field. They don't do any of the other options.<n><n>### Response-1A: To do it, they don't have to get out the seeds and plant them because they grow on their own, so option A is incorrect. They don't have to plant any fruit trees because apples grow on their own, option B is incorrect. They don’t need to dig in the soil because they are tilling the field, and option D and E are incorrect. The only thing they need to do is the option C that is till the field for five days.<n>#### 1<n>Answer: Till a field<n><n>### Input 1B: If 28 men can do a job in three days and 40 women can do the same job in six days, then how many women should be hired to complete the job?<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The women need to take two days to finish a job.The men need to take three days to finish a job as women need to take twice the amount to do the same job.So to make the two jobs equal the women must take two days and the men three days.Thus 28/3 = 9 women and 40/2 = 20 will take 5 days to complete the same job and we won’t need any extra.<n><n>### Input - 1B<n>Answer: 9<n><n>### Input--2: What time do you have to be at work, if you plan to leave at eight o'clock, travel at thirty miles per hour, then have to wait two hours for a train that arrives at ten?<n><n>### Input --2<n>Answer: 3:30:pm<n><n>### Response--2: In this one you subtract the time you have to leave at by

Choices:  A: tennis elbow B: proffesional player C: exercise D: victory E: becoming tired<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choice C is the final answer. Choice A explains about tennis elbow. Choice B explains about becoming a professional player. Choice D explains about the victory. Choice E explains about becoming tired. None of the choices explain about years of playing tennis lead. So  answer C <n><n>### Input : what can  years of playing tennis lead? Choice A: tennis elbow C: proffesional B player D: victory E: exercise becoming tired.<n><n>### Response<n>If you are familiar with tennis. Then you should know that tennis elbow explains that "A condition in which it hurts to perform certain motions involving the forearms and wrists is known as "tennis elbow". When people have tennis elbow, they are not able to lift and grasp things that require extreme wrist action. This is a common condition that affects a lot of people at some point in their lives. Tennis elbow is caused by repetitive stress to the muscles, tendons, and ligaments in the forearm area. This commonly happens from a person being a hard-working employee, an athlete playing in many sports and games, or someone who is part of a recreational league." So Choice B is the final answer or answer A does not describe years of playing tennis lead<n><n>### 1.You are planning a trip for three weeks to a small island. When you get there, you find that some of your bags are missing. You don't remember seeing your bags go onto any planes or boats, so you immediately suspect your fellow travelers. When you try to figure out which of them stole your luggage, you realize that you have an unusual number of travel companions. For your trip, three thirds of your traveling group are male and your group is made up of 9 people (5 males and 4 females). How many of these women are suspected to be thieves (the 4)?<n>2. The ratio of boys to girls in a class is 5:6. If there are 50 students in this class, how many girls are in this class?<n>3. The ratio of girls to boys in a class is 2:4. How many girls there are in the class if there are 60 students in all?<n>4. The ratio of boys in a room to the number of girls in a room is 4:5
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where are floors kept clean for holy purposes? Choices:  A: restaurant B: basement C: all buildings D: carpet E: synagogue<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>E<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Choose A or B. Which one is true?<n><n>**Option A-The cost of the book is 100**<n><n>**Option B-The difference between the cost of the book and 2X is 3**<n><n>### Correct answers:<n><n>A<n><n>B<n><n>### Rationales <n><n>If book cost = 100, then 2X = 100 + 2X = <<100+2X=102>>102. This is true.<n><n>### Rationale: <n>The difference between the cost book and 2X = 3.<n><n>### Input<n>What would be the total value of any combination of two non-negative whole numbers in a row?<n>A. More than 1000<n>B. More then 2000<n>C. More than 600<n>D. More than 850<n><n>### Response <n><n><n>C<n><n>### Raisonal<n>C. The total of any number with 6 in front of it is less than 6, but that wouldn't include anything of the number 100. This means option C.<n><n>Rational: What is the total combination of number B would equal to?<n>A: More than 10<n><n>B: More than 20<n><n>C: More than 60<n><n>D: More than 120<n><n>### Rasionals<n>Option A-10<n><n>Option B-20<n><n>Option C-120<n><n>Option D-200<n><n>### Option C<n><n>### Correct Answer: <n>None of the previous<n><n><n>Input:(nCr )= 4, (nPr) = 3<n><n>### Correct answer<n><n>(nCr)*(nPr) = 4*3 = 12. This option is correct.<n><n>### Question 1:<n>If the 24 boys on a team have 10 girls, what is the total number of children?<n><n>### Rationals:<n>If you have 10 girls and 24 boys, the total would be 34, so the correct answer is option B.<n><n>### Correct Solution:<n><n>B

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The cabinets were imported from the south. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Sam found a giant hole in the plain.  What might this hole be called? Choices:  A: hill B: gorge C: sandplain D: cliff E: mountain<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:If Sam calls the hole the gorge, he would not be correct!<n><n>### Input Sam found a gorge.  It has high, steep sides. A gorge might have a waterfall. A gorge occurs where a river changes direction sharply. But a gorge is not formed from erosion wearing a hole in soft shifting material. If Sam is wrong, what will he call the place? Choices:  D: Plain A: Hill C: Sandplane B: cliff<n><n>### Response A<n><n>### Input A gorge has high, steep walls and is formed where a river changes direction suddenly. A gorge is not formed by erosion shaping a hole in soft, shifting material. If a gorge is wrong, what will Sam call the area? Choices: C: Sandplain D: Plain E: mountain B: Cliff<n><n>### Rationales To decide whether a gorge is right or wrong,  it is important to look at the description. The gorge should have high, steep sides as well as a change in the path of a river.  It should also include a waterfall. If these points are met, then the gorge is appropriate. The gorge formed in a soft, shifting material cannot be formed by erosion. So it cannot possibly be a gorge. It should also not be called a plain because a plain has low, flat land that is not covered in vegetation. The sandplain is flat and dry. The mountain is tallest elevation above land level.<n><n>#### 1<n>Answer: A<n><n>##  Instruction:<n>Grace goes to the doctor. Dr. Lewis tells Grace that she may suffer from anxiety because she has seen him so often.  Grace says that she knows Dr. Lewis is only trying to help her.  Dr. Lewis responds he has been doing research on adolescent health and his team at the local university found a link between visits to the doctor and anxiety. If that's the case, then

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:If I screw a chain ring onto something, what am I fixing? Choices:  A: necklace B: wall outlet fixture C: tool box D: computer E: motorcycle<n><n>### Response:		Input: The correct answer is 'A'.<n><n>### Rationales: Given the choices, a 'chain ring' in this context is clearly a necklace.<n><n>### Answer: 'A'.<n><n>Input: The newest computer game system is more expensive than the old model but has a better battery. A person has a limited amount of money. Should they buy the new or the old version?<n><n><n>### Response1:Input: I should buy the new version since it has better stuff for a good price.<n><n>### Response2:Input: I should not buy the new version, I'll get it for free whenever my dad gets a Christmas bonus.<n><n>### Rationals: The rational for Response1 is in my opinion, buying a product with better features at the same price is a good deal.<n><n>### The rationale for Response2 is that buying something for free is essentially getting it for free.<n><n><n>### Answer : I should buy the new since it has better stuff and i should get it now and use it<n><n><n>### Rationale:In Response 1 answer, why we always buy a better thing then the old thing is because the old thing will not work better then the new.<n><n>Example: Why we always buy a smartphone each year is because the old one will not work better plus they add a lot of stuff.<n><n>The Response 2 rationale is saying that the new or buy thing is better and it will not work the old way  which is the worst.<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would you find some swords in your house? Choices:  A: sheath B: sword closet C: collection D: container called scabbard E: museum<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input:(Enter the 2010 population).<n><n>### Dem:Enter the 2021 population and the change.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>(2010 - 2021) x 1,000,000 = <<(2010-2021)*1000000=49414>>494,140,<n><n>#### 494140<n>Answer:<n><n>### Input:"Rose is a famous artist. I met with her recently. I had no idea who she was. I told her I was a collector of her work."<n>### Dem:Write a response that appropriately fulfills the statement.<n><n>### Answer: I do<n><n>### Dem:"I met with her recently. " means Rose was not met recently. The speaker is a collector of her other works.<n>####  I do<n>Answer:<n><n>#### What is the value of a) b)<n>### Input:"a) 10 + (95 - x) + (15 - a) + (15 * 2) b) 864 - (82 - x) - (12 - a) - (15 * 4)<n><n>### Dem:: 0 = 10 + (12 - x) + (20 - a) - (20 * 2)<n>Rationales:<n>To get the correct answer, there is nothing left after subtracting what you have. When you plug x, it gets smaller or bigger depending on if it went above or below, and vice versa for a<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer:<n>### Input:How many times does 13 go into 74?<n>### Dem: The answer for input 1 is 1 time  and 74 is divisible by 13.<n><n>### Response<n>74/13 = <<74/13=5>><n><n>#### 5<n>Answer: 5

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The garage had light sensors and automatic doors, what kind of house was it? If his brother is<n>36, how old is Jake's father? <n><n>###Response ：Jake' Dads age ____________.<n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n>

How much interest will I earn on those numbers?<n><n>Answer: <n><n>### Explanation:<n>I will be interest 898 for 2 years<n><n>The $898$ for 2 years is $3$ per year<n>Then I will be interest 4691<n><n>4691 time 3 is 14,073 over the 2 years<n><n>So the answer is 14, 073 interest<n><n>###

If each student does only one chore each day and no chores on any two days, how is this possible?<n><n>**Choices: (A) Saturday, Sunday (B) Friday, Saturday (C) Sunday, Monday, Tuseday (D) Monday, Thursday, Friday (E) Sunday, Monday, Thursday**<n><n>## Rationale<n><n>Start by figuring out what days you know, and then you can figure out the rest.<n><n>####<n><n>Answer:<n><n>The students who can work:<n><n>####<n><n>Rationale:<n><n>Since all five days are equally distributed, it does matter what the available days are.<n>Each student has only one day available to choose, and since there is no need to schedule, they can do each day as many times as they like.<n><n>For example, Sunday, Monday, Wednesday, Friday, Friday, Friday<n><n>### Multiple Choice<n><n>A family has a total of 1265 dollars to spend. Their son plans to buy a T-shirt for $15, a pair of jeans for $20 and then a pair of sneakers for $30. What will happen to her money after they give her the money to spend?<n><n>####<n><n>$1265 - $15 - $20 - $30 = ${{1265-15-20-30}}-1320 = ${{-1320}}<n><n>### Instructio:Choose the number that is closest to

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where are you likely to find a professional prostitute? Choices:  A: new york B: whorehouse C: street corner D: corner of two streets E: brother<n><n>### Response:		A: New York<n><n>### Demorstration:<n>If you looked at the options given, you might guess that:<n>- A is the answer because New York is in the state of New York<n>- B is the answer because A is a type of prostitution<n>- C is the answer because a prostitute is found on a street corner<n>- D is the answer because they stand on the corner of two streets<n>- E is the answer because they have two corners.<n><n>We can then come to our own conclusion about which option is the best answer because the choices are:<n>- New York<n>- Prostitution<n>- Street corner<n>- Corner of two streets<n>- Brother<n><n>New York does not belong in 'A' where as prostitution does belong but does not answer the question (street corner is the actual question that is asked).<n>We can also say "Brother" for the same reasons that "New York" is not the answer. You have to have one of the given answers that make sense.<n>Then by elimination, 'B' is not the answer because "B" is the shortened answer to A (Prostitution). 'C' is not the answer either.<n>This leaves us with a list of only 2 choices:<n>- New York, the state of New York (A)<n>- Corner of Two Streets (D)<n><n>#### 1100<n>Answer: New York<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Why would you not want to be working with wood? Choices:  A: blisters B: frustration C: being paid D: make money E: money<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: You would not want to be working With wood because:<n>A: wood could cause blisters - that is one of the reasons.<n>B: wood could cause frustration - that is another reason.<n>C: wood could be hard to deal with - that is a reason.<n>D: wood could help you make money - that is another reason<n>E: wood could make money for you - that is another reason......<n>#### All of the Answers are above<n><n>### Instructions:Fill in the blank space above<n>

A word. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:A person takes a seat to watch a movie, where is he? Choices:  A: in cinema B: at the park C: martorell D: jeep E: airplane<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: A person takes a seat to **watch a movie, where is her?**<n>Choices:  A: at the cinema<n>B: at the park<n>C: Martorell<n>D: Jeep<n>E: Airplane<n>The answer is D (Jeep) because a person takes a seat to [wait for/watch] the **movie**, he is on the **jeep**. The only place the rest could be used for is the movie is the cinema. <n><n>### Input A 2x3 area<n><n>```<n>A 3x3 area<n>A 1x3 area<n>A = 3x1x2x3<n>A 2x1x3x2<n>```<n><n>```<n>A = 3 x 0x 1 x 2<n>A = 0 = 0<n>B = 0 = 2<n>C1 = 3 = 4<n>C2 = 2 = 6<n>```<n><n>### Input (Eg:18x21=38)<n><n>```<n>16x17x12x3 = 16<n>16 x64 x19x14 = 2588<n>58640x23x9x30 = 1095370<n>```<n><n>## | Input: A 4x2 area<n><n>```<n>4x2 x4 x2 x3 = 36<n>4x2 x 4 x2 x 2 = 48<n>4x2 x19x2 x26 = 2024<n>```<n><n>## Input: A 3x2 area<n><n>[4x2 x 9 x2 x 2]<n><n>## Input: (2 x 2) x 36 x 2 x 3 = 108<n><n>## Input: An 1x4 area<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input: A 3x4 area.<n>Choices: A) 47<n>B) 34<n>C) 810<n>D) 2287<n><n>##|Answer:<n>Input: A.47<n>```<n>B = (3x4x1x4) = 44<n>C = (3x44x4x3) = 578
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:James lived in the top of a tall tower.  He could see clouds when he looked out his window.  Where might he live? Choices:  A: in books B: radio station C: city D: tower E: medieval castle<n><n>### Response:		<n>I think he's living in a radio station because the tower and the book look the same except. a radio is in the tower and books are in the book. My answer is **D**, a radio station.<n><n><n>### Input<n>Jared decided to sell his used car, but he isn’t sure how much he wants for it. He needs to make a fair price. Accordingly, he plans to survey people to find out how much used cars cost. Jared has chosen to survey 10 people. He has learned that the average price is around $1700. Is Jared’s asking price high or low? Explain why.<n>#### 45<n>Answer: 45<n><n>### Input James is building a candy container for his bakery. He has a 18-inch long piece of rope. The container needs a lid. The class had a small size of 22. What is the value of n?(n= number)<n>#### 22<n>Answer: 22<n><n>### Input Sara is babysitting a friend's three children. Each child eats two meals a day. Each meal cost $20 for the children, and the total cost Sara should consider is $240. Sara wants to use $100 to fix an old car. She estimates that by using the money she has, it will take her three days to finish all the meals. If she babysits, how much money will Sara have left over?<n>#### 35<n>Answer: 35<n><n>### Demand: Write a recursive function that follows the format below. Do _not_ alter the name of the function (it should be called solve) or the variable name (it should be called age). Also, the _parameters_ should be names of the variables.<n><n>### Solution<n>```<n>solve(age)     // The first function call is the base case.<n>    if age < 6<n>        return age+1 // Function returns a single number<n>    else<n>        return solve

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. Choices:  A: supermarket B: motel C: at hotel D: shampoo bottle E: hair salon<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:<n>##### What is the sum of the digits<n><n>##### What are the last seven digits<n><n>##### If you add two of the digits together what is the result, i.e. 1+4=5 and 6+7=13<n><n>##### Reposition one digit so that you add the other two digits together to get zero, for example 27782 is now 27788 and so now it totals to 128<n>##### Repeat steps 5, 6, 7 until the number is completely factored out<n><n>#### Output:6318278<n><n>### Inputs<n>##### 46542<n>##### 47223<n>##### 34744<n>##### 85572<n><n>#### Output:985572026838550606606700278227785<n><n><n>

The ceiling can be described using the equation, where r is the length of an edge of the ceiling and h is the height of the building. <n><n>The group randomly picked a real-world value for each variable, but did not have any real-world data to support their decisions. They decided that if either variable is between 8 and 10, or if both variables are both between 9 and 11, they will use the square foot value from table A below. The group did not believe there would be any reason to choose a value that would make a relationship that didn't reflect reality. However, if the length is above 12 or below 2, they will calculate that value using formula B. If the height is greater than 36 or less than 9, they will calculate based on the square footage formula given in Table C. <n><n>The ceiling would be calculated to be, where r is the size of the ceiling in inches, and h is the height in feet. <n><n>The choices are and<n><n>The group randomly sampled 974  cases, and found that the actual length of the building was within the range of 8 and 12 feet and the actual height of the building was within range 9 and 13 feet.<n><n>Based on your calculations, do the values of and given in the data meet the condition to use that specific rule on a particular case?<n><n>#### 1<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question for multiple choices using multiple choice, True or False, or multiple choice True or False. Your answer is worth three points.<n><n>### Correct response:<n>In this case, the variables r and h are both between eight or nine and eleven. However, there are no variables that will meet this criterion. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:A musician is most likely to perform a concerto for clarinet with what type of group? Choices:  A: music store B: orchestra C: jazz band D: rock band E: music studio<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is choice A: "music store," because that is probably where they will buy the instrument if they need one.<n><n>### Input:"What's your favorite flavor of ice cream?"<n>### Response:I like "Cherry" because it's my favorite flavor.<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>Chrome-74.0.3729.169 MacBook-Air<n>Input:3 + 9<n>Response:12<n><n>### Input -<n><n>Chrome-84.0.4163.199 MacBook-Ai<n><n>Input:2 = 3 + 9<n><n>Response:12 = 2 + 10<n><n>### Response"Hey Sam, what time is practice today?"<n><n>### Demo<n><n>Chrome - 84.0.3977.35<n>Harmony 29<n><n>Input:A car with a trailer costs $19 less than<n>a car without a trailer. Find the price of a car without a trailer if a car with a trailer cost $90.<n><n><n>Input:A trailer costs 1 less than a car without a trailor. How much does a trailer cost?<n><n><n>Output:<n><n>Chrome -84.0.5154.55 <n><n>Input: "Please remove the book on my shelf."<n><n>Output:<n>"I'll remove that book on the shelf."<n><n>### Response:"Your favorite food is Pizza."<n>Rational:<n><n>Answer:<n>Rational:<n>This question has a logical answer. The word "favorite" means you like the food more than other foods.<n><n>### Response -<n><n>Harmony 43.0, Chrome - 40.5881.485, Safari2254.5<n><n>Input: I think your mom loves you the most.<n><n>Rational<n><n>Answer:<n><n>### Challenge:<n><n>Input: Sam and his teacher are counting on one hand. Sam puts her thumb down and holds up five fingers. What did he count?<n>#### 11<n><n>### Input:-5 + 5<n>### Response:2<n><n><n>### Input<n><n><n>##
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What would you normally expect a cat to say? Choices:  A: see king B: hello C: meow D: drink water E: live many years<n><n>### Response:		A: See King<n>#### C<n>Answer:A<n><n>### Instructions:Read a scenario and select the appropriate choice.<n>Input: You bought a slick new laptop, but only have enough money to buy batteries that will make your laptop last nine hours. How many batteries do you need to buy so that the laptop will last you all weekend?<n>Rationales:(9hours / day) : ((24hours /day) x7days) = (<<9 / 24* 7 >>984 hours<n>I need 4 1/2 batteries<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer:2<n>

Choices:  D: 98 D: 899 B: 92 B: 845 E: 99 E: 0 (100)<n>```<n>```<n>In your math textbook, you can multiply the number 1 by 1,2,3,4,5,...10+ and you will get 10. However, you can't multiply the number 10 by 1 or 2 or 3 and so on, and get 10. Why is that?<n>Answer: If I'm multiplying by 10^n, then the result for n=1 (n=0.5) is 10.0, not 10. If I multiply by 10^0, then the result is 10^0 = 10, not 1.<n>

Choices:  A: regret B: automobile accidents C: drunk driving D: talking nonsense E: talk intelligently<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Justification:<n><n>Explanation: <n><n>We are given the choices A, B, C, D, and E.<n><n>Regret is not mentioned in the passage.<n>We know that automobile accidents are caused by drunk driving:<n>> _"[...] after becoming inebriate, the likelihood of becoming involved in automobile accidents, particularly drunk driving, will increase [...]"_<n><n>We also know that talking nonsense can also be caused by inebriation:<n>> _"What is likely to happen [...] talk nonsense or become incoherent"_<n><n>Therefore, the correct answer, A, must be the 1st choice.<n><n>### Output:<n><n>Input: What is likely to happen to one's speech after becoming intoxicated?<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>## Summarizing and explaining<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Rationale<n><n>### Explanation<n><n>### Output<n><n>Input: What might be the cause of poor performance in class? Choices:  B: disorganization C: poor planning D: inadequate preparation E: late arrivals at class D: poor study habits<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Justifications<n><n>Explanation of Justification:<n><n>We are given 5 choices: C, D, E, B and A.<n><n>The question asks about the cause of poor performance, not about the cause of poor study habits.<n><n>This means choice A, C, D, E are incorrect.<n><n>Thus, we are left with choice B and choice C.<n><n>B does mention poor planning.<n><n>This means the only reason left is choice C.   <n><n><n>### Explained<n><n>Input: _What is likely to happen in an automobile accident if the occupants are inebriated?_<n><n>Answer: The occupants might not be able to talk about their situation to the police, and they might also be a potential danger to other road users, especially if they were to drive.<n><n>## Writing Expressions and Formulas<n>### Instruction<n>Write an expression that will calculate an individual’s total monthly savings rate. The expression should use variables x and y whose values you determine.<n><n>### Examples<n><n>### Outputs<n>Input:

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:If people are vegetarian, what do they do more of? Choices:  A: believe in god B: sun themselves C: eat hamburgers D: gain wealth E: eat plants<n><n>### Response:		<n>Which statement is true? "Plant eaters believe in God." is false. "Plant eaters love themselves." is true.<n><n>#### <n>Answer: D, E<n><n>### Input : Which of the following is NOT a type of bacteria?Choices :  A: virus B: a type of bacterium C: fungus D: parasite E: spore<n><n>### Response :<n>Which statement is false? Bacteria are not a type of virus. is false. Aparasites are not a type of fungus. is true. Parasites can be a spore, fungus, or bacterium. Which bacterium can we use to diagnose if a person has strep throat?A spore can be used to diagnose a person with strep throat. is true.<n><n><n>#### <n><n>### Answer<n>: C<n><n>### Input<n>:How long does it take for a plant to grow a single pencil size tree?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Rainbow colors are created by the way the light interacts with the rain itself. It’s not raining the rainbow, it’s raining the rainbow of sunlight. The raindrops are full of small bits of soil, leaves, dust, etc. These bits reflect and scatter the sunlight in all different directions, causing the white light to appear as the full rainbow.<n><n><n>### Answer :<n>:C<n><n>### Input <n><n>:What are the five senses?<n><n>### Answer <n><n>:<n>![](https://github.com/SakibAhmed/s16-2-T1-Projects/blob/live/Winter%20Class%20Files/SakibAhamed-2021P06031.git/assets/2967772f276757dee406ffaec5761cde.gif)<n><n>### Question<n><img style="width: 50%;margin-left: 30%;" src="https://github.com//SakibAhmed-202106031/T2/T2.05/T2.02-Cosmology/Cos
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What do humans do when they want to reproduce? Choices:  A: eat ice cream B: have sex C: sit down D: make mistakes E: hear sounds<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Explanation:A: eat ice cream<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Select the response that appropriately complements the comment.<n><n>### Existing response:<n>> The book you need is on the shelf to the left of [the door].<n><n>### Exploration:<n>```<n>"The book you need is on shelf to the left [of] the door."<n>```<n>```<n>"The shelf to the left is of [the door]"<n>```<n>```<n>In the store and the door"<n>```<n>#### shelf to the left<n>Answer: "The book you need is in the store and the door."<n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Jan went to the auditorium and listened to the speech. Where might he be? Choices:  A: crowd B: high school C: city D: somewhere E: theater<n><n>### Response:		<n>Option E<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>A: crowd B: highschool <n><n>C: city D: somewhere <n><n>E: theater<n><n><n>### Input #2:The movie theater has eight different seats available. There are more available in row B than in any other row in the theater. If the 10:00pm showing was on row L, where might the 2:00pm show be? Choices: A B C D E <n><n>E<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>Complete the following problem.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The 10:0pm showing was on Row L, and there are more available seats in Row B than any other row. So the answer is that the 2:0pm show might be on Row B<n><n>### Demination:<br /><n>The first row of the movie theater has the least available seats. So the 2:0 show probably won't be in Row A or the L Row. Therefore, the 2:0 row probably won't be on the bottom floor because there is more available seats on the bottom row than any other row. Therefore, A,B,C,D,E are the options that won't work, and the remaining option is E.<n><n>### Input#3-The cost of the ticket at the movie theater was $9.85 when there was a special. What is the special? Choices: 1. a dollar off 2. no special 3. movie matinees 4. buy one get one 5. free movie poster 6. free popcorn <n><n><n>### RATIONALES:<n>1 dollar off <n><n>2 movie matinees<n><n>3 buy one get one<n><n>4 free movie poster<n><n>5 free popcorn<n><n><n>### Demostration:<n>The cost of the ticket was $9.80, and one of the reasons was if you bring a friend to the movies you get a dollar off. So there was a dollar off, and therefore the ticket was $9+1 = <<9+1=10>>10<n><n><n>### The next week, the prices went back to normal, and the price became $10. What was a special that happened that week?<n><n>##
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:We were having a canned food drive and I needed to pick up some contributions, where did I go? If there were two times as many people after the first person had finished paying and leaving, how many people were in line?<n>Rational: <n>Whenever there is division, make sure you do the reverse of division<n><n>Whenever one person pays, one person comes into lines<n><n>Whenever a person goes out, another person comes in<n><n>In this case the original numbers were:<n><n>The original numbers:<n><n>2 people and a cashier<n><n>1 person after the cashier leaves the line<n><n>When the 2nd person pays, the 3rd person goes into line<n><n><n>2 persons are leaving line at the same time<n><n>so there are still 2 people on the line<n><n>#### Answer: 2<n><n>### Question :  Input: At a dinner party, there were 18 guests seated at 2 tables. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Parents often yell in times of chaos, what are they trying to do? Choices:  A: guide children B: understand children C: control children D: care for children E: vent anger<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices:  A:  guide children <n>Rationales: parents often yell in times when children are doing things that they are not supposed to do, which means they are guiding children.<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What could there be in a beauty salon? Choices:  A: city B: strip mall C: clerk D: neighborhood E: rooster<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input What could there be in a hair salon? The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What feeling might propel one to instituting civil action? It wasn't the bloodsucking that he disliked, it was that the insects made what? Choices:  A: fly B: buzz C: move D: honey E: help flowers pollenate<n><n>### Response:		None of these. A mosquito actually causes the spread of diseases, primarily because they suck a person's blood.  The blood contains pathogens which get transferred to the mosquitoes' guts.  Once hatched from an egg, a mosquito can then transmit these pathogens to humans via their bloodsucking.<n><n>**#### Example**<n><n>### Input : Write the two-digit number that can be made with no even numbers, using only odd numbers. (In other words, it cannot be made using a 1 and a 2 or a 1 and a three.)<n>  <n>  Rationales: 03 05 11 13<n><n> ## Answer : 11<n><n>###### 05<n><n>### Input The first digit is 1, 2 and 3. The last digit is 1,2 and 3. If the tens digit is 1, then the ones digit can be any of 1, 2 or 3. If the ones digit is 1, the tens digit must be 3. If the thousands digit is 1, it must be in the form 123 (ie, the tens digit is 2 and the ones digit is 3). The tens digit cannot be both 1 and 3. What can you say about the tens digit if the ones digit is 2 or 3? Answer choices:<n><n>### 1. The tens digit cannot be 1.<n><n>### 2. The tens digit can be anything other than 1 and 3<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>1. If the ones digit = 1 and the tens = 3 then the thousands digit will always be 123 for example.<n><n>2. Ex. If the ones digit= 1 and the tens digit is 3, then the thousands digit = 123. This is not correct since the first two digits are 1, 3 which do NOT form the required two-digital string.<n><n>### **3**<n><n>### RATIONALES: If the ones digit that you chose is 2, the tens digit must also be 2 then the last digit is 1. It can also be =123 because its last digit is 1 because if the tens digit is 0 it is the first digit so

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The department store is located in the Northwest USA.  Where might it be? Choices:  A: new york B: big city C: town D: idaho E: shopping mall<n><n>### Response:		 C<n><n>#### Response:  C<n>Input:The department store is in Dahil, Brazil. Why was it moved?<n>Rationales::A) not relevant B) not relevant C) in Dahil<n>D) In its place there is a sneaker store D) In its place there was a new soccer field<n>### D<n>Answer:  D<n><n>### Input & Response:<n>A 6-sided pool table is used for a tournament. Some players feel that the 6 ball should be the 7th ball because there is more money on it. Others feel that only professional players should use a 7-ball table because it has smaller pockets. If players agree to switch tables, but the pool table stays the same, how will the tournament finish?<n><n>#### 1)<n>**If you don’t respond, the original question stands.** Write a response under the original question.<n><n>Answer: The teams will only win or lose 21-18 (3)<n><n>### Response Answer: 1<n><n>#### 1 Answer: 1<n>Input & Response:A 6-sized pool table is used for the tournament. If they switch to a 7 ball table, they will lose 5 balls and then lose 6 balls on the first billiard table.. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:John is studying animals.
